column10: its awesome and takes time to get to know where everything is at but other than that it is a good game

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is the latest entry in the popular simulation series that lets players run their own car repair shop. The game features over 70 licensed cars, 4000 unique parts, and various tools and stations to work on different aspects of the vehicles. The game aims to provide a realistic and immersive experience of car mechanics, from simple oil changes to complex engine rebuilds.

The game has two main modes: career and sandbox. In career mode, players start with a basic garage and take on various jobs from customers, earning money and reputation. The jobs range from easy to hard, and require different skills and tools to complete. Some jobs are straightforward, such as replacing a battery or a brake pad, while others are more challenging, such as diagnosing a faulty part or restoring a junk car. The game also offers optional objectives and bonuses for completing jobs faster or with higher quality.

In sandbox mode, players have access to all the cars, parts, tools, and stations in the game, and can work on them freely without any time or money constraints. This mode is ideal for those who want to experiment with different cars and customizations, or just enjoy the process of fixing and tuning cars. Players can also buy and sell cars in the auction house, or test drive them on the race track.

The game's graphics are impressive, with detailed models of cars and parts, realistic lighting and shadows, and smooth animations. The game also has a dynamic weather system and day-night cycle, which add to the immersion and variety. The sound effects are authentic and satisfying, with the sounds of wrenches, hammers, engines, and tires. The game also has a relaxing soundtrack that fits the mood of the game.

The game's controls are intuitive and easy to use, with the mouse and keyboard or a controller. The game's interface is clear and informative, with helpful hints and tutorials for beginners. The game also has a comprehensive encyclopedia of cars and parts, which can be accessed at any time.

The game's main drawback is its repetitiveness and lack of innovation. The game does not offer much new content or features compared to its predecessor, Car Mechanic Simulator 2018. The game's core gameplay loop remains the same, with players doing the same tasks over and over again. The game's difficulty curve is also uneven, with some jobs being too easy or too hard for the player's level. The game's mini-games, such as repairing parts, balancing tires, or washing cars, are also simplistic and tedious, and do not add much to the game's fun factor.

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is a solid upgrade for the series, but not a revolutionary one. The game is a must-have for car enthusiasts and fans of the genre, who will appreciate the game's realism, diversity, and customization. The game is also a good choice for casual players and newcomers, who will find the game relaxing, educational, and enjoyable. However, the game is not for everyone, as it can be boring, frustrating, and monotonous for those who are not interested in car mechanics or simulation games.

Ultimately a fun little game to flip restoration projects, but eventually it becomes tedious and repetitive after a while. Generally all of the cars are one of a few designs, and you won't encounter true proprietary part layouts really outside of the engine, and even then I wonder if it's still 100% accurate to real life. The biggest let down is the lackluster car sounds. You spend hours polishing and repairing each part, making it glimmer, and then you take it for a test drive only for your minty $300,000 car to sound like a leaf blower. It would be neat to have a team of people become hireable to do easy jobs like oil changes and tire rotations, make it feel like an actual business instead of a random garage in the middle of nowhere.

Few considerations:
1. If you're looking to increase your car mechanics knowledge this game is for you. Play a good amount of hours, then inspect a car in real life and you're going to easily recognize its components.
2. This game is great to waste hours and relax. There are different ways you can play this game. Personally i like to grab cars from junkyard and make them new and shiny.
3. If you grab the Drag Racing DLC you're going to have fun tuning your cars so that they can perform against other cars in drag race.
4. The only thing that's missing from this game in my opinion is a city environment where you can drive your car and enjoy it as if it was really yours, this makes it almost pointless to own cars in the game. Would be amazing to get in your car, get on the road and drive until the city or whatever (there is some material on the workshop though). That would make great multiplayer content aswell. Nontheless you can use your cars to do laps in the race track, go in the speed track, test track or drag racing (DLC) which can be fun.

Overall if you like to mount and unmount stuff, repair things (or create) to make them shiny new or in good condition, and you want to expand your cars knowledge I highly recommend this game to you.

Not a bad game if you didn't own CMS 2018, it's pretty much the same game as 2018 with a few extras like a machine to repair and restore disk rotors for the breaks and they added all the fluids which you can change out. Not a big change and it's my opinion it's not worth creating and selling a whole new game for the minimal amount of items added which could have easily been added to 2018 as DLC. Now if you had CMS 2018 and purchased this new version you have to spend money to repurchase all the DLC over again which I don't like, the whole package makes me feel like i am being taken to the bank just to play the same game. the whole shop set up looks a bit different but who cares.

I think we could do with out the mini games within items like the tire balance which is now more unrealistic then prior and you get locked into the action while the tire is being balanced and can't walk away and do something else. I kind of liked that you had to wait a short period while the tire was being balanced and could go do something else and return to retrieve your balanced tires. And the CMS2018 tire balancer even sounded spot on.

I like the scraping idea yet i have upgraded many parts and then while doing it items are upgraded yet they show that there is no gain in value to anything from what i see it shows 0% prior to and after upgrading parts so what is the sense of it all and once again you have to sit through this painful mini game just to scrap parts, I hate it. They should add a feature so you can shut off all mini games if you don't like them which from reading in the suggestion area is most people, not sure what the developers were thinking there.

All in all it's OK especially if you never purchased CMS 2018 but for some one like me who owns CMS 2018 and put countless hours of game play into it you feel like you have been taken advantage of and for the most part sold the same game at a higher price and left to repurchase all the same DLC you own in CMS 2018. I see this new culture arising especially on steam where a developers creates a game and then instead of progressing the game they just stop adding new content and then for the most part create the same game and call it a new version with a few new items. I don't like this and it doesn't say stupid on my forehead, I will be avoiding these type of purchases in the future as they come around.

Delightful combination of a puzzle game and a resource management experience. Lots of play styles (informally: renovator, repairman, racer) allow you to truly make this game your own.

Some simulation games suffer from the "what now?" issue, but not CMS. The cycle of buy junker --> renovate junker --> sell for five figures of profit is insanely addicting. Taking your first car to the speed and race tracks makes you want to build your second one even better. Doing jobs starts out as a frustrating experience and becomes a satisfying puzzle as you play. "What the heck is wrong?" turns into "This problem is so simple that they shouldn't have gone to a mechanic," and from there the dopamine hit of knowing what's wrong without even checking is epic. That being said, I recommend checking CMS forums if you're a new player and forgot where your fuel rail goes for the fifth time.

DLC is there but not mandatory for the game to be enjoyable. All 40 hours of game play as of this review being posted were done entirely base game, and I see many more hours of enjoyment ahead without DLC.

I personally don't mind this, but some die-hard mechanics might not like the simplicity of certain aspects of the cars. For example, you don't bleed brake lines and some components (battery, fluid reservoirs, etc) float around and aren't necessarily connected to anything. It doesn't negatively impact the game play, but don't use this game as a training module for real-life repairs.

Not accurate enough to be able to start working on cars, but close enough that you'll begin to recognize components of a car in real life. This taught me to become fascinated enough to look into repairs myself, and they look *way* less scary after having "done" them in the game because all the parts aren't just metal/plastic black boxes any more. Might have even inspired me enough to go to school to learn automotive repair. I was never really a car guy but this game might have made me into one, time will tell. What I can tell you, I find the game a Zen-like experience and I personally love the soundtrack.

Yes, it's a good game. Is it going to keep you occupied as long as you'd hope? No not really. The game itself is pretty enjoyable up to a point when you realize that the only thing that makes this worth playing for over 20 hours is the DLC. The DLCs are extremely overpriced when you take into account that mods are free. The only DLC really worth paying for is the drag racing dlc because they didn't just add races, they took an important part of building a raceworthy vehicle (carb/ecu tuning) and locked it behind a paywall. The driving mechanics are terrible when you consider that any indie game that's ever existed has had better vehicle control than this mess. What's the point of building your own vehicles if you can't drive them without ripping your hair out because the physics are incredibly poor. And what's with the lack of content lately? Adding a few new parts to build like 2-3 cars from a new manufacturer and then keeping it as a paid DLC really doesn't improve the game. There have been no free base game content updates since its conception. Why hasn't there been an overhaul for visuals in the 2 and a half years this game has been out? Everything is still just rust. You already have a pouring animation for fluids, why not animate oil leaks into the game. And why are we still playing a minigame for repairs? There are numerous tools that mechanics use and yet none of them exist in the game

I absolutely friggin' love it. The more detail I can get, the more realistic, the more I learn and the better. I would appreciate random "pop up" tips, that you could turn on or off or perhaps a tool (a question mark) that you could use to get random knowledge about all these various things (their basic function and more). Like if you're changing the coolant (just an example) a tip could educate the player what the coolant is for. And that you could use water as a temporary measure if you're not in a cold climate. And perhaps say why it's important for the engine. The sum of both playing around with the different parts and getting tips every now and then, would be amazing, for anyone who is just starting out to learn about cars. You could maybe even set it to "beginner tips" or "intermediate tips" or "pro tips" ... or a mixture of them all. Or... maybe a sidekick that you could talk to in real time and ask questions. Oh and multiplayer would be great too. 

Anyway, love this simulator and I say simulator because it's more than "a game". It's highly educational. I'd love it even more if it had a 2016 Land Rover Discovery Sport or a 1992 Ford Explorer so I could learn about my own cars. In a perfect world it would have ALL of the cars. ALL of them. Looking forward to what you have in store in the future. And this would obviously be AMAZING in VR.

P.S. Extreme realism mode would be ftw

I was hoping this might be a good learning tool for basic car maintenance and component identification but I was disappointed with the lack of any real explanation about the tasks we were doing. The tutorial tells you to push buttons and open menus but gives no explanation about the how or why. It feels like it was designed for a mobile game. Push button, receive reward, repeat. "OK, now you know how to be a mechanic!" Yeah, no.

I think other reviews here have said it better. The entire game is clicking and holding on stuff and watching stiff and simple animations play out, that's it. Diagnosing a problem is as basic as just looking at the health% of a part and buying a new one. 

The engine bays are also of questionable authenticity. The 2017 Ford Mustang in the Ford DLC is all over the place, fluid reservoirs and fuse box are in the wrong place and are generically modeled. There is a fluid reservoir for power steering that shouldn't even be there because this car has electric power steering.

When I first bought this game I did not expect it to be this good, I thought it would be a simple indie game, but no! It is a highly polished and very realistic simulator of being a car mechanic! Sure, it's missing some elements that could make it even more realistic, like VR support. But I think the amazing graphics make up for not having VR. This game teaches the core of what it is like being a car mechanic, like having a teenager pull in their destroyed car into your garage saying that he was trying to impress a girl. All in all, I haven't played a lot of simulator games but I would say this is a perfect game for anybody who wants to get an idea of what it's like being a car mechanic!

been a fan of this game franchise for awhile, and I gotta say, this one is a really good step-up from the 2018 version with so many new features, functions, cars, activities, etc. Considering I really like anything to do with cars, this game has been a real help in my learning process, it can't teach me everything, but I sure wouldn't know a whole lot had it not been for this game, and the 2018 version too. Not only that, the DLCs for the game are super affordable and totally worth it. However, if you do buy the DLCs, I suggest buying the mega pack rather than just getting a few of them individually, since having only one or two doesn't make a big difference on the gameplay. I also heavily recommend checking out the workshop, it's a great way to find a car you can't find in the game. that's all I have to say on the game though, sorry if I went on for a long time, but I totally suggest the game!

i have a bunch of hours accumulated and i don't recommend this game if your looking for a simulator. if your into fixing up cars and not concerned about realism then this game is probably for you. i have been working in the auto reconditioning field for many years. the game for me is bitter sweet. i can think of numerous improvements to add for both the fun and realistic side of things. 

i'll give you an example of a car i  just purchased at the auction. i paid roughly 10K for the car through bidding against AI. sometimes you get a decent deal and most other times you take a slight loss. condition wise i had to buy new parts for about 80% of the car which is very unrealistic. and the prices seem very high.

as far as detail in the car it is nice but could use some improvement.

i do like to take on jobs and upgrading tools and the shop in general is nice.

i did make some repaints of cars and i do not recommend it for most. most all the cars are hard to paint because the parts are all strung out. they should have aligned the parts as they are displayed. for instance a whole side of the car as you would see it facing it. it is very hard to align stripes for example. so they made what should be an easy job hard. it's a shame because i do like custom painting cars and adding different stripes.

i do hope they offer a new game in the future with improvements. i would like to see more realism and an easier method of making custom liveries. an auction service to buy parts would be a nice touch with the ability to buy used engines and other parts. this way you could fix them for better profits. they also need to add much better accounting. i never really know what my profit margins really are. this way you could keep proper business records. and we are in business to make a profit. knowing how much you made is a big part of the satisfaction for your efforts.

Super fun and shockingly educational. Went into this not even knowing how brakes work (embarrassing, I know) and now know enough about cars to know I know nothing about cars--and if you're familiar with the Dunning-Kruger effect, that says a lot. This game is essentially a super complicated puzzle game except you get to build a collection of gorgeous cars that you put a ton of super satisfying work into. There are a few minor annoyances but luckily if you get lost you can look up basically anything and someone else has made a tutorial or posted something to a forum. Overall, I'm obsessed with this game and I'm not even a car guy. Would recommend to people that enjoy puzzles and finding patterns, people that love automotive vehicles of the personal variety, and people that like games that involve building a business or making money.

Car Mechanic Sim 2021 is honestly one of my favorite games ever! It is super relaxing and great to just sit back and listen to music while you play.  It also has a ton of great DLC that add even more cars than the base game already has! If you are like me and want even more cars though, there are tons of mods in the Steam Workshop that you can use. There are only 2 features that I think this game is lacking: Multiplayer, and a showroom/warehouse for your cars. There is a parking alley already in the game for your cars, but you can't really see them too much. It would be super cool to walk into a building, and just see all of your cars together.  Other than that, this game is amazing, and would 100% recommend this game to anyone interested in a super chill mechanic sim.

I hardly write reviews for games, but I thought I'd have a go at it now, right?

[h2]Short version:[/h2] 
Generally, I really enjoy the game and it's a good way to destress after a long day, definitely worth the money. But there are some things that could be better, especially UI and not locking things behind DLC (a problem Simulator genre as a whole experiences).

[h2]Long version:[/h2]
[h3]What I liked[/h3]
Now, I am not a motor-head and knew absolutely nothing about cars before playing this game, of course, except for the fact that they have 4 wheels and an engine :D . But this game taught me a lot about what makes up the car and really made me realise that we as humanity tricked a bunch of metal to move us from Point A to Point B. So yeah, I think this game can be a great way to learn about cars, especially when you do not have a car to disassemble yourself. This game also relaxes me- I feel that I can tackle orders at my own pace and make a playthrough my own, without needing to prove anything to anyone, which is a great quality for a game and a gamer like me. With a game this open ended, it's easy to set your own goals, which is another great quality of this game, and simulator/tycoon genre in general. I also did not experience any major bugs in my almost 20 hours of playing, which is a big plus.

[h3]What could have been better[/h3]
- UI- the main menu looks a little too simplistic and the crates you get for completing story orders are simply textures, to show that they open, rather than an animation. 
- The soundtrack is pretty limited and among the 3 radio stations, all music sounds exactly the same. I appreciate the option to turn off the music though, I enjoy the game without it more anyway. But if you want music, just play your own playlist off a music service. 
- Money management- I felt like it can be a little difficult (playing on Normal difficulty) to manage expenses if you do not know what you're doing. I had to restart my progress because unknowingly I spent money on upgrades and ended up not having enough money to complete story orders. Side orders hardly pay anything, depending on complexity and bonuses, of course. I wish there was some kind of loan system, or simply increase payouts/reduce prices. But at the same time, it's not necessarily a negative as difficulty to make profit can provide a great challenge to keep going forward and keep coming back to the game.

[h3]What I disliked[/h3]
- DLCs- This is a problem the entire genre suffers as a whole, rather than this game, but I find that a lot of the content that is said to enhance the gameplay is locked behind DLCs that you have to purchase separately- as if you haven't already paid £20 for the game! Some content, such as Drag racing and Electric cars should have been part of the base game to begin with, in my opinion. And speaking of Electric Cars- I bought the DLC as I felt like it was the only one that would enhance the game, but only 2 ECs spawned in my gameplay with the DLC active, which is insignificant. Other DLCs- I felt like big brand car packs would not add much value to the existing game but correct me if I am wrong.

[h3]Verdict[/h3]
I give this game a solid 8/10. If more ECs (that I paid for) spawned and UI was a little better, the score would for sure be higher.

[h3]Helpful tips if you want to play[/h3]
When starting out, focus only on Story orders, and side orders that pay bonus CR. Do not bother with garage upgrades/tools (unless needed to complete the story order) and spend your skill points on Discounts, so you make more profit. As I mentioned in my What could have been better point, money is pretty tight in this game, so use it wisely. If possible, you could cheese it by getting parts from the Junkyard, but it is very much down to RNG.

My third purchase of the CMS series.   Like any game, there are up/downs to everything as things evolve but I'd like to say this had enough to make it feel progressive than just a new coat of paint.   

The biggest rant I have its having to repurchase any DLC/brands that I want but I learned that on the 2nd iteration.  So I went from buying all of them to only the 1 I care about as I can go backwards to the other versions if I want them. 

The biggest flaw is the driving, it just is...laughable in physics and purpose.  All the cars sound the same and drive like a potato.  It just really has no purpose other than potentially figuring out what is wrong...but should be done via the path instead anyway.  I'd be ok if it was totally removes so developer time/resources could do more to the game.  

I didn't like the hours I had to spend to deconstruct items and the minigame.  I can tolerate all the rest (brakes, wheels(loved!), body), but the scraps I HATED!!! Just get rid of it overall and have a salvage all like there is a sell all over a certain % wear.

Actually pretty nice, definitely better than car mechanic simulator 2018.

Positives:

+ Graphics are improvement compared to the older one. 

+ relays, brake fluids, coolant, power steering fluid (might get repetitive later on but I love that they added these)

+ better car roster (in my opinion), cars are much more true to their real life counterparts.

+ / - better dlc, for some this might be on the negative side because you have to pay for dlc but I honestly think they are worth it especially if you get them on sale.

Now for the negative sides of the game, currently haven't found really anything negative about the game but I do have one gripe

Negative:

- Early game is SUPER SLOW even compared to cms18. Feels like unscrewing speed and screw speed overall is decreased by 50 %, although this could be only me.


EDIT: Game is overall pretty good, not yet finished the story since I have done side quests and mainly did the main quests to get money for restoration of other cars. I have already sinked a ton of hours in the span of couple days. Planning to 100% the achievements in this game

Pretty much an exact clone of Simulator 2018. They've added a couple of minor things, but they haven't done much to improve the game at all. On top of that, they've added a dozen things that break the game. Here's a list of reasons you shouldn't buy the game

1. As noted: this is about 95% the same as Sim 2018. All that's different are the cars and some minor changes to repair/etc. 

2. The "minimum repair %" breaks the game, as you have to know exactly where every item came from originally - whether it static or not. This means that if you put one - just one - of the 16 camshaft caps in the wrong place, you have to pull them out and start again. Don't get me started on how frustrating this is if you put the wrong piston in the wrong spot. And the only way to fix this is by using highlighting - which doesn't work if you remove the engine to work on it. It's not realistic (sure, a mechanic will need to be pretty careful with moving parts, but a lot less careful with static parts), and it just makes the game unenjoyable. 

3. They haven't added any of the useful improvements to the game that you'd have expected. For example.  In 2018 there was no way to tie repairing/building a vehicle with the junkyard. IF you have a list of 50 parts you want - you'll need to write them down on a piece of paper / notepad, and then go to the junk yard. This could have been fixed SO FUCKING EASILY  by just having the shopping list be accessible from the junkyard. 

4. And to top the above off, there's no borderless full screen, so if you have a separate screen with a notepad on it, then you'll need to use non-full screen mode, or just minimize each time. Which is just fucking stupid

There are more things which I can touch on, but this is a good start.

On the positive side, you can just click on an item in your shopping list to go straight to it on the shopping page. I didn't know this until about level 13, so I was a bit pissed, but it's good to know...

tl;dr Games a great mechanic sim which is exactly what it advertises, so for that I have to give it the thumbs up, if you like car building games this is THE car building game.

Long version:
Got it for about 14 bucks and honestly 22 hours to beat it is fair for the price, but I feel like I'm wishing for more. I got sick with covid the day I got this so was isolated in my house and managed to beat this game in about 2 days, fully refurbished the Lamborghini Diablo, beat the race track and the main story. Fully upgraded the car garage, went into over 30 barns, was really just burning right through the game to be fair, but it be nice if there was more to do.

It lacks a certain replay-ability and endgame, after you have rebuilt 1 or 2 cars you have rebuilt them all, and lots of the missions feel tedious or identical to the main quest. On-top of this once you unlock the skill that lets you estimate the value of cars money is never an issue again because you can buy cars and instantly resell them for massive profit, making all the quests pretty much pointless.

Game quickly wen't from a cool simulation into an almost sandbox game (on normal that is). It delivers exactly what it says it will but unless you REALLY like rebuilding the same few engines over and over there's really only 20-30 hours here, which is fair, but all in all I give the game a solid 7/10. Would love some attention to the end game and economy to make this a game I can sink hundreds of hours into, but for what it is, it's a very solid game and probably the best car building game out at the moment.

I didnt expect much, and i wasnt terribly disappointed, but in the end, i cant recommend this one. its not really a game, its an animation player. you hold down the button and watch animations play.

it certainly has some educational value, and its nice to look around the cars and play with the parts. its silly in places (you can "repair" a clutch friction disc as if it was a brake rotor), and missing a lot of details, but thats all fine, its a game, not a technical manual.

what killed it for me, in the end, is the lack of real control over anything. you just remove parts and add parts in sequence, and do almost no diagnosis or anything interesting. in order to remove pistons, you must disassemble the head. not remove, disassemble. cam rockers and everything have to come completely apart, if you want to replace piston rings. its tedious and frustrating.

its fine for what it is, and if you're looking to click on car parts for a moment, you'll be happy. but if you want anything intelligent out of this 'game', forget it. as a game, its barely more than a cookie clicker.

This game is properly enjoyable and you also learn something along the way. I've repaired dozens of cars - several rebuilt from the ground up - and it never gets old. Whether stocking up on parts from the junkyard to store for later or building a car from the first bolt, the interface is intuitive and the building very satisfying. 

Featuring a dyno for performance tuning, a paint shop, an area to ensure your tires and headlights are aligned, upgradable parts in the shop, engine swap opportunities, custom tires and wheel combinations and all the items in the trailers above, I'm yet to find a flaw. You may occasionally zoom in on the wrong part and get your view out of whack, but a simple pan out or re-selecting the proper part will set you straight.

I have recently added the Porsche, Jaguar, Land Rover, Mazda, Lotus and Pagani DLCs. The first 3 of those boast the most content, but the others are also solid, plus the Paganis will sell for the most by far when repaired.

I rarely give a game a 10/10, but this one truly earns it.

Once you complete this game ( after restarting a billion times ), you'll feel confident enough to work on your car IRL ( please don't ). Overall: Amazing game and experience

I'm pretty handy around a car. Not a total greasemonkey, but I do most minor repairs and regular maintenance myself, which I'd assume is the audience this game should be targeted at. Somebody who owns an actual garage isn't going to be playing around in a virtual one, and anybody who's not a fairly intense car geek won't be interested in spending hours simulating car repairs.

Unfortunately, this game lost me from the very first car. To change the oil, the game makes you unscrew the oil drain plug, drain the engine oil pan into the drain pan, then PUT AWAY THE DRAIN PAN before it lets you remove the oil filter. Any 17-year-old vocational student who's ever done an oil change knows you leave the drain pan in place, since removing the filter releases a ton of used oil!

Right then and there, it became impossible to take this seriously as a "simulator" if it gets the most basic thing in car care -- an oil change -- wrong. A small detail? Definitely, but it's the sort of small detail that's noticeable to the target market for this game.

Fantastic Game literally hours of enjoyment! I got this when it released and it has been a stellar experience so far. The DLC officially licensed cars are great and all the things you can do to the cars as far as fixing, building and tuning is top notch! But in my opinion the game is lacking a few key features. 

#1 Transmission/Gearbox rebuilds.

#2 More replaceable exterior items (e.g. windshield wipers, headlight and taillight bulbs, radio antennas etc.)

3. More in depth interior customization (e.g. seat color and material type, dashboard/rearview mirror items e. g. fuzzy dice and sunglasses.)

4. More in depth tuning options (e.g. replacing carburetor jets, tuning turbochargers and superchargers, as well as allowing for twin turbo and twin turbo supercharged engine setups!

5. More engine swap options on more cars, as well as AWD, RWD, 4x4 and FWD drivetrain swaps
(Let's be honest who doesn't want to make the Fast and Furious Tokyo Drift Mustang with a Nissan RB26 R-34 engine in it?!!)

6. More Paint booth options (e.g. applying decals, stickers, vinyls and custom paint schemes.)

7. More officially licensed vehicles as well as more varied options (e.g. a monster truck or Dragster would be sick.)

Other than those few cons the game is incredibly fun and will keep you entertained for hours on end!!!

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021, developed by Red Dot Games, proves once again that fixing cars can be oddly satisfying in the virtual realm. The game provides an immersive and detailed experience for automotive enthusiasts, offering a deep dive into the world of car restoration and customization.

One of the game's standout features is its attention to detail in recreating the intricate mechanics of real-world cars. The comprehensive list of available car models, each with authentic components and a variety of issues to address, provides a genuine sense of being a hands-on mechanic. The level of realism in the repair and restoration process, from disassembling engines to tuning and testing, adds a layer of authenticity that car aficionados will appreciate.

The game's user interface is intuitive, making it accessible to both experienced mechanics and those new to the genre. The well-organized garage, comprehensive toolset, and straightforward tutorial system guide players through the complex tasks of automotive repair and restoration without overwhelming them.

The addition of a photo mode allows players to capture and share their customized and restored vehicles, adding a creative touch to the gameplay. The in-game economy, where players can buy and sell cars, parts, and completed projects, adds a layer of strategy and progression that keeps the experience engaging.

While Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 excels in replicating the intricate world of car repair, it may lack the storytelling or broader objectives found in other simulation games. The gameplay loop, while satisfying for enthusiasts, might not have the same universal appeal as more narrative-driven experiences.

In conclusion, Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is a solid entry in the genre, offering an authentic and engaging experience for those with a passion for cars. Whether you're a seasoned mechanic or just curious about the intricacies of vehicle repair, this simulator provides a satisfying journey through the virtual garage, making it a noteworthy addition to the Car Mechanic Simulator series.

The game itself isn't bad unless you played cms2018 then there is almost nothing new to experience. cms2021 feels pretty much like a copy paste version of cms2018 with a few new little features which are nice but that's too little. Even most of dlc cars are the same which feels like a money grab considering that you gotta spend almost 100$ to get the whole content.  cms2021 still suffers from the same problems: terrible user interface, annoying camera work, overall huge lack of quality of life improvements. Diagnostic tools have slow animations, same with manual examination. I was about to fall asleep while watching same boring animations. Economy is also shit. You get so little money for fixing cars that you quickly start looking for alternatives and then you realize right away that there is no point in doing anything else than flipping car you buy from auctions. 1h job can give you profit of around 2k while flipping a car even 10 times more within a minute. Driving model is same bad. I was super hyped for the game but now I'm super disappointed.

TLDR: if you have cms2018 skip this one - game has almost nothing new to offer, still have same issues. If you are new to the cms series and wanna give it a shot then it's a game for you. Unpolished but fun for a while.

Honestly, the game is an offense against actual car repair. How to fill engine oil? What's that you say, add some then check the dipstick? Nope, just pour oil in until it gushes out the top

Replacing brake fluid? Need to bleed the brakes to draw the new fluid down into the lines and calipers right? You know, the entire purpose of replacing the fluid in the first place? Nah, just pour it in the reservoir until it overflows and you're good.

If you want a toy that's vaguely related to cars, I guess it's alright? I'd have enjoyed this as a child. If you're looking for an actual car sim, look up Wrench.

Thought it might have been a real issue so tore down the block then systematically everything else. I then cackled loudly and yelled to my dog, "You see Dexter?? You see it was a GD bushing??!! That's why this almost perfect car wouldn't start!" Because a bushing keeps cars from starting IRL. Next time I take my car into the shop I'll make sure the mechanic replaces all the bushings so I know it'll start. Simulator fail.
Amazing quality Game

Having played the original 2015 version, this one surely is an upgrade but after 6 years and a different release in between (CMS 2018), it feels like the game could've been so much more.

My biggest issue with the game is the audio design - it's *exactly* the same as the 2015 version - no joke, everything from loosening the nuts/screws to filling in fluids. By now I would've expected different SFX when pouring motor oil, windshield fluid or literally any other fluid - they're the exact same sound despite having different viscosity 

To add, I was so disappointed when I drove the cars on the race track... The sound is a pain to the ear and the handling is atrocious and uncharacteristic even after wheel alignment, it's just not fun. Many mobile racing games do this part better which is a shame imo

I loved finding cool cars in barns or in auctions so I can fix 'em up all the way to perfect condition - hell, I love installing every performance part that I can possibly fit, but having those HP and Torque numbers go up mean nothing when it's not fun to drive or race either way

Still, I recommend the game because it has kept me pretty entertained and invested in cars, especially throughout my car mechanic studies

If you liked the 2018 version, you'll definitely enjoy playing this one as well. They've added brake, power steering, coolant, and window washing fluids. I like that its more realistic by slowing down the base mounting and screwing speed, and that the job pay and car selling prices are lowered. I bought a bolt hellcat at the junkyard for around $6,000, put about $30,000 into it, and sold for $60,000. The previous game would have sold for $100,000+ and it somewhat made it too easy/relaxed. It adds more of a "challenge". I've ran out of money while doing a job, and had to sell a junkyard car that I had recently purchased at a $2000 loss just to finish it. I also really enjoy the new and improved engine sounds, and engines. They even have a diesel! I highly recommend this game!

Incredibly fun, a nice relaxing game that I find very enjoyable. Due to some of the DLC's and Workshop mods, the game is infinitely replayable, and can be very rewarding after each finish of a car. I love the in depth models of the vehicles, and the accuracy of the parts to the real thing. 

Some parts of this game could use some reworking, however. 

- I feel the bodywork is very limited, and it could use a little bit more spicing up. (Such as more body panels, pieces of the chassis and body underneath the panels being removable, and more in depth damage to the body and parts).

- The Driving is very rushed. You can only drive on certain small tracks, and the physics feel very choppy. Cars with high horsepower can spin out really easily, and you cant ease into the throttle due to the limitations of the keyboard. Also when driving on tracks, if you crash your car there is no consequence. Even a damage toggle in settings would be interesting, as it would add a more personal feeling to your vehicles. The last thing to complete the driving aspect would be the addition of open world driving. This is a bit far-fetched, but being able to drive around a city (even if it is empty), would be very neat especially in the car that you just spent a few hours rebuilding. All of these together would make for a more immersive and personal experience, with stuff such as regular maintenance of your vehicles after use or accidents.||

- Live Auction House, where online players can go and bid on other's vehicles, and list their own. Along side the in game auction house, this would make selling your car more fun, and buying cars with specific tunes and such easier, as long as they can pay for it. cars can be bid on infinitely, and people could also list for a BIN. This would also add an alternative to the basic "sell car" feature in game, as it could allow people to sell their car for more money, if they can wait for someone to buy it. 

- More Add-ons, Engine swaps, addition of car lifting and lowering, splitters, and extra customization to allow people to create their own dream car easier. 

Now, even though i have written a whole essay above on improvements, those are simply my opinion and some are a little far-fetched, even outrageous. All in all, this is a wonderful game and i would highly reccomend you pick it up when it's on sale (which it is every month and a half or so) if you are interested in cars and auto mechanics.

Looking through the feature set for 2021. It looks like the major changes include

Missions

Dents

Car Wash

What is missing most for me is any level of multiplayer. I'd settle for being able to download someone else's saved lap on a track to just give me another car to look at while I'm driving.

I only recently bought 2018 when it went on sale on Steam, and I felt like after I had reached the point where I could afford to go to auctions and restore cars, all I was really doing was a lot unscrewing, purchasing and rescrewing to look at a car mod I'd downloaded.

I like the core experience of the game, but find myself wanting more. Can I compete against another garage (even if it's AI?). Can I advertise or upgrade the exterior to try to attract more customers? Can I hire people to do the mindless grunt work while I focus on running and expanding the business? How can you be a good garage if you don't answer 99% of the service calls? Why aren't I building relationships with my customers? Shouldn't I occasionally host or attend some kind of classic car auto show?

I am sure I will eventually get CMS 2021 but there isn't anything about it (that I can see) that makes me feel like I really need it to come out right away.

A Gearhead's Paradise - Car Mechanic Simulator 2021

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is an absolute gearhead's dream come true. This game not only provides a fascinating and detailed look into the world of automotive repair but also stands as a testament to continuous development, offering a comprehensive automotive experience with a touch of education.

The core of the game revolves around the incredibly detailed car restoration and repair mechanics. You begin with a modest garage and gradually work your way up to a world-class workshop, all while tackling various jobs, from simple oil changes to complex engine rebuilds. The game meticulously replicates every part and component of a car, allowing you to disassemble, diagnose, and fix problems. The satisfaction of taking a beaten-down junker and turning it into a shining masterpiece is truly unparalleled.

The inclusion of an ever-expanding list of licensed car brands adds a layer of authenticity that enhances the overall experience. The DLC packs available for Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 offer additional licensed cars and extra challenges, making the game even more captivating. From muscle cars to classic vintage vehicles, these DLCs provide an array of options for car enthusiasts to indulge in.

What's especially notable is the continuous development and support the game receives. The developers consistently roll out updates, new content, and improvements, ensuring that the game remains fresh and engaging. This commitment to delivering a polished and evolving experience is highly commendable and keeps players coming back for more.

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 also acts as a surface-level educational tool. While it won't turn you into a certified auto mechanic, it does introduce you to the basic principles of car repair and maintenance. The game encourages you to learn about car parts, their functions, and how to diagnose and fix various issues. It's a fun way to gain an understanding of automotive mechanics without getting your hands dirty in the real world.

In summary, Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is a game that's truly a labor of love for car enthusiasts. It offers a detailed and immersive experience in the world of auto repair, with licensed car brands, DLCs, and a continually evolving platform. It's a fantastic way to get a surface-level understanding of how cars work, all while having a blast restoring and customizing vehicles. Whether you're a car aficionado or just looking for a unique and engaging game, Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is an excellent choice that keeps evolving to satisfy your automotive cravings.

This is a really fun game. I have zero interest in cars at all, but thought I would give this game a try when it was on sale. I see it as a type of puzzle game, trying to find new parts, and then trying to figure out where all the parts are meant to go. You can take jobs from customers, find old broken down cars that need a lot of work, or cars that need a few things done, then sell them, or keep them. You can take pictures of the cars you have worked on.It's very relaxing. The only thing that I would like, is when you look at the list of things that need doing on the car, you can have the option to add all of the parts to the shopping list from the parts needed list. Either way, I highly recommend this game, if you're looking for something relaxing, satisfying, easy and just need to "switch off" for a couple of hours.

This game has no business being this fun.  Responsibilities? What are those? 4 days. 4 DAYS of doing nothing that I should be doing because I can't make myself not reopen the game on my PC first thing in the morning, and on my Steam Deck while waiting in the car. I'm getting eye strain headaches every day, but does that stop me? Of course not. I just finally reached a point of closing the game willingly after 51.4 hours; well worth full price, let alone the price I paid on sale (I got the main game and several of the expansions.). I probably should have expected this after Thief Simulator so captured my attention, but I never learn.

If you're at all interested in mechanics or understanding how engines work, you'll probably enjoy this game. It's not completely realistic, there are a lot more parts on real cars (and in real life there's this thing called transmission fluid that would need to be drained when opening the gearboxes), but if you only have a general idea of how engines are built, you will learn more about how complex they are and maybe understand more about the engineering behind them.

I'd love to be able to actually drive from place to place with a simple map, or even just be able to drive my cars around the garage; something to consider for possible future games...I hope. *hint, hint*

This game is absolutely addicting and amazing. I love it. I'm not really in to cars, but I do maintenance on my own vehicles, so I'm kind of familiar with most of the parts. The level of detail is incredible.
Although they do remove all the wiring and hoses from the cars. It would be nice if they included the major ones, like the radiator hoses. 

The shop customization is great, but the repair and salvage parts are lacking. For the repair, I wish they would let you break down the individual parts and replace minor things like wiring and orings, etc. Actually rebuild the part and not just play a mini game. Repair seems more of an after thought compared to the rest of the game. I also wish the warehouse was more integrated into the game. Right now it's just extra space. It would be nice if your computer/tablet contained a program that would show you your inventory.

They go really detailed with the engines, but not so much with the transmission or front/rear differentials. I don't have any DLCs yet, but I didn't see any notes on these being implemented. I saw the manual transmission was added with one of the DLCs.

It would also be helpful to have an app that would show the readouts of all the diagnostic. I know it'll flag the parts that are bad because of the checklist, but not the parts that don't meet the minimum standard. I would like to see the status of all the parts I checked, in a list,, versuses just looking at the part.

Buying parts is instantaneous. It would be kind of neat if they implemented a timing system. It takes x amount of hours for the part to arrive. This would delay the repair of the vehicle and then have your customers call and pesture as to why their car isn't done yet. Then you could put a chain link fence off to the side and store all the cars not repaired yet. That would give you a proper mechanic immersion. 

I know I out a lot of wants and nice to have ideas in the review, but it doesn't diminish the quality ofbthe game. It it is well done and very enjoyable to play.

First time I've seen a car not start because suspension was worn out... You can't properly diagnose what's wrong with the car without buying every tool, you can't buy every tool without money, you can't earn money if you don't finish a job, you can't finish a job because you don't have all the tools. Progression in this game is completely abysmal.

It's fun and engaging when a list is provided or when you can test drive the car or use tools and obd scanner to find out what's wrong. Jobs should be locked off until you have the tools to diagnose the problem.

EDIT: On inspect mode you can click and hold to inspect A FEW parts, but you still need the tools to get the whole picture

Story quests should be blocked until you have X amount of money to work on the car, without delving into the job you have no idea how much money you'll sink into it. It's easy to run out of money in the middle of a car fix and then having to take 20 fluid/filters jobs to buy the parts to keep working on the first job

Engine sounds are awful as well. They are all very generic and bad quality, they rarely match the revs.

All in all it's a fun game, but you gotta be prepared to hit your head against the wall often

This game is an excellent simulator, for someone like me who knows nothing about cars. Not sure how accurate it is but I feel I'm learning a lot!
Some of the story missions are interesting, it would be nice to get a little message of thanks when you finish a story job though. It would be much more immersive and it's nice to be thanked for doing a good job (I get really sucked into being the mechanic)

The only main things I have an issue with are below:

- I'm almost max level and getting parts from the junkyard to salvage is just not worth it.
I recently decided to go to the junkyard and pick up everything. I repaired what I could and salvaged the rest.
It took me nearly 2 hours. 
There needs to be an auto repair or auto salvage at higher levels. It's just not worth anyone spending enormous amounts of time on the mini-game to save a few credits.
Time is money after all.

- The above leads into the issue with the Warehouse. What's the point of having it if you can't use anything in there without it being in your inventory?
At the bare minimum, I'd like a little icon when installing a part, to show if you have one in stock in the back room. That way, I'd use it all the time. At the moment I'm lugging around 200+ parts that I repaired just so I know I have them.

- The Dyno doesn't do any explaining on how to use it. I've no idea how to tune a gearbox and I struggle with it. From what I've read elsewhere, other people struggle too. Great for people who know what they're doing. Not at all intuitive for people who don't, which means we just won't use it.

- If you have a race track, you need to fix the driving mechanics because they're incredibly clunky. I get it's not a racing sim and I respect that because the mechanics side is wildly fun, it's just a thought. Also races would be great if that's an area you would delve into in the future.

In summary, this is an excellent game that I can relax and play for hours on end. It just needs a couple of QoL tweaks to be perfect.

I mean, seriously, this game should come with a warning label: "May Cause You to Abandon All Responsibilities!" I used to have a normal life, you know, but now it's all about rusty bolts, engines, auctions, junk yards.

First of all, let me clarify that I absolutely despise this game. I hate it so much that I'm playing it right now as I write this review. My productivity? Gone. My social life? Non-existent. My self-control? Well, let's just say I have about as much self-control as a squirrel at an all-you-can-eat nut buffet.

I wake up in the morning and think to myself, "Today is the day I'm going to quit 'Car Mechanic Sim...' I've got better things to do!" But then, just as I'm about to hit that uninstall button, I suddenly realize there's a '73 Mustang waiting for me in the garage. It's like the game knows when I'm weak and vulnerable.

The worst part is, I now have this inexplicable urge to check out real-life car engines. I've started hanging out at auto repair shops, pretending to be knowledgeable about carburetors and camshafts, all because of this hocus-pocused app. 

I hate this so much, I want to quit it like cigarettes, but I can't. It's a game that has turned me into a grease monkey, a car enthusiast, and a procrastinator of epic proportions.

You don't have to know how to repair cars to play this awesome sim.  I think it's certainly an advantage if you are car savvy, but not a huge one.  There are good tutorials and the game makes it pretty easy to learn what you'll need to know. 
I like the relaxed pace of the game.  You'll get all the time you need to completely tear down that engine, rebuild the suspension, do all the body work you want, and more.  Players take the roll of mechanic in their own, newly opened, garage - doing everything from oil changes to full transmission rebuilds.  The garage can be upgraded to offer new services like window tinting, detailing, diagnostics, and others - and there is a nice variety of awesome tools that make the job easier.
There is even more to do than repair customer's cars:  
Players can also visit junkyards, barns, and auctions to find their own cars to rebuild.  The cars can then be driven on test tracks / race tracks - and then there is even an option to keep them or sell them.  
Players can move through a story (or not) at their own pace, controls are simple to learn and consistent, and the cars and components are highly detailed without being unnecessarily complex.  There are so many different cars and parts that I consider this to be infinitely replayable.  I think this game is for you if you like working on machines, games that involve upgrading, slower paced games, or if taking things apart and putting them back together is interesting / cathartic / fun for you.

What the game is really missing are some missions of car orders. Meaning that someone would call you and tell you he/she needs car type of this horsepower and willing to pay certain amount of money. Also the tuning could be little bit in more depth.

Keep in mind the game is dead and developers dont care about it. Every 3-4 months they re-release one of their older dlcs and thats it. Game is missing key features like for example filtering items in painting menu or colouring more items at once. Consider this before you purchase the game.

TLDR: 1:game has no guidance; you need to google everything to know where it is. 2: buggy; randomly doesnt let you complete a task, making the job impossible to complete. 3: graphics are jittery 4: UI an unorganized hellscape
very cool game, very mechanics, much wow
games tutorial teaches 3 things and says "draw the rest of the fucking owl"
from there it drops you quite literally in the middle of the desert without any further guidance
after 5 minutes of struggling with the UI you finally get to taking your first order, yay
then it gives you a checklist of things you need to do to fix the car, understandable
but heres where the baptism through fire begins
want to know where the oil filter is? maybe the fuel pump or air filter? too bad; you thought this was a mechanic simulator? its actually a scavenger hunt simulator
wasnt aware the requirements to play this game were being a real mechanic to know the layout of every engine bay on every model
finally figure out where that pesky oil filter is? sweet! now you gotta memorize the type of oil filter or check your inventory every 2 seconds to remember that exact part to order, find the part in the unorganized part catalog, and even then enjoy getting it wrong and having to go back to the part order 3 more times :)
an extra frustrating element is some of the tasks are literally uncompletable
order came in - replace window washing fluid, ok ez i can do this. nope, game literally didnt let me unscrew the cap
ive done it on 2 other cars but this one wont let you, does it tell you why? no
another order - checklist: tire... what about the tire? does it need to be balanced, maybe new tires altogether, youll never know hee hee but oh, if you want to put new tires on it you cant anyway so get bent
my final complaint is that you cannot get rid of a car unless you complete the tasks - so if the game bugs out and say... doesnt let you put a wheel back on for no reason - your garage is permanently blocked and you have to make a new save file
0/10 being a real mechanic would straight up be less frustrating
there are better mechanic sims on roblox

So far - this game seems like it will be fun for anyone who knows absolutely nothing about fixing cars - "so far", with the added attention to details. I've only just begun - and as a lover of sim games, I like this one's approach. That said, it feels like an AMAZING 1st step in what could be an amazing mechanic sim game. In fact, I am tempted to buy the DLC just for the fun of working on other vehicles that are more mainstream, but I am still reluctant based on this game missing a lot of details needed to truly be a full "simulation" of an auto shop. So, for now, I give this a 5 out of 10 stars (And will update as I get further in), I am glad I waited until it was on sale though - cause it still needs work, and unless the simulation incorporates more reality (like I recommend here) or depending on what the game already has, I am reluctant to tell you to go out and buy the DLCs, too. 

So, here are suggestions, I hope the programmers see this: First, the shop itself: It would be more "sim" if we were doing clean-up, getting it osha / hazard safety ready, and "setting up" our shop (and I know this is a from scratch shop - but everyone does some basics and improves over time and I'm here to play a sim game - which these days, sim games have lost some of their oomph, but this game's attention to detail on the repairs thus far is so good that it's a shame not to take it to the next level). Next: the operations: while there is some good detail given to the parts replacement: they need to change out their parts buying schema to be more like nexpart multiseller and show the dealer vs client cost (where different vendors may specialize in things like electrical, but multisellers are industry standard and the program should let you enter the car and part and find the vendors for you ... and a simple search online for Autofluent or Shopmonkey will show you how the software works). They need to use a diagnostic tool like Autel for odb reads, key fobs, code clearing, and tpms (etc - and you will see this being done on Youtube even, as this is industry standard now, and is a service in and of itself). I highly recommend they add a Motor or Mitchell1 brand / autofluent style interface for parts/labor costs, schematics, designs, etc. - because that's how mechanics find where parts are located and the steps required (really, every shop has this option because no one person can know everything about every car. And, discovery is time consuming and time is money. And, you can even go on some very reputable websites and find this type of info - so, as this game does cater to "not real" mechanics while having some level of reality that I think could be actually educational, adding this feature would be a game changer!! And - if you know a mechanic and mention mitchell1 or Motor or even nexpart- at least in America, they will immediately know what you're talking about). Using this type of in game parts buying interface, Players can also learn to look up cars by license / vin like they do in real life and find the differences in car stats from one model to another (which you can do with the NHTSA right now - for free, so that would be an easy add-in & vin's are either read off by the diagnostic tool or physically/visually). By using Motor brand or Mitchell1 (Motor is preferred these days) software with "set" per job labor rates (as is industry standard and should be part of any "sim" game), budgeting and even quotes for work could be added (as custom rates are rare and only for "custom" jobs in which players could challenge their times and lose money for going over), and this could be easily used to generate a metric of work vs time vs cost vs income (and players could compare themselves / their work to other players and that would be another awesome feature). This could even let players generate invoices and see their monthly accounting - and while that may sound like overkill on detail - once you do that once - you will love it and never go back because... you see how much money you're actually making!! Even hand tools should be *at least* shown for their per job use & "consumed" per repair with a 0.01 - 0.03 degrade per tool until 100% and then player has to buy new tools (most shops actually charge a shop tools fee as a % of a job to compensate for tool wear & tear, so this is real life stuff). We should be able to choose from a series of icons (like wrenches, gears, pistons, etc. - easily found using a google search or ai for auto shop iconery) and names and layout styles for the front of our shop to really customize it and make it "ours" (we could even have a sign up in the shop, too, showing our shop name and brand icon/logo, on the front door, the street sign out front, and as we build cars, print it on the side of our own custom cars and license plates and that would be "branding" and an awesome feature for fun (seriously - you could even let players choose from 1 - 6 colors to represent their "shop", hang a uniform with these colors / designs on the wall with the player's name embroidered on it so they get a sense of how they look, and incorporate all of this to really make the experience more "customized" per person and that would give a player a sense of personalized ownership in what they were doing - which is the point of owning a mechanic shop vs. being an off-the-shelf mechanic working for someone else). All of these elements are real-life mechanic shop elements that could seriously augment the quality of this as a simulation game. Goals could then be set -> amount of labor time per job is known vs type of job and type of car to estimate which jobs are the best to take on (Motor or even the Napa ProLink online gives that type of info for free) -> the in-game calendar time could be generated, and you could set goals to be achieved like a minimum net income per month by X month based on how many jobs you do per day (a 15 minute oil change vs. a 45 minute diagnostic and wiring job), or a larger goal like opening a second garage by X month, or earning enough money to add new lifts and tools to your current garage, etc. The Autel or other diagnostic tool could incorporate the real life key fob programming - another awesome that can throw this game over the top (and those services could be limited until a key fob is unlocked and the online mfg key programming class passed so that you can't offer that service for the added income until you've earned it). You could use nexpart to choose between parts dealers and get the best list / stock price for you... OR... for your customer (a balance that real life mechanics have to make - which sometimes is as simple as cost + 30%), and that changes how much business you get vs your competition. It's easy to look at Napa ProLink and Autozone Pro online - both free and both offer a lot of the same types of baseline job quoting info to draw from if the programmers don't want to access more serious levels of auto mechanic shop software to draw from. You could also be forced to deal with factory only parts and add new challenges to costs and parts acquisitions for "custom" jobs. You could add in scheduling and calendar appointments to force a mechanic to get backed up as a challenge (whereby, taking too long on a job starts losing value per hour on that job and could cost you money - and budgeting / scheduling is a real thing!!). This simulation should also estimate costs including the amount of fluids per job to know if you're pricing the job right. Mechanics is fun - but far more than just fixing a car. Anyway - if you like any of these ideas - comment on this and tell the programmers so we get their attention as I would LOVE to see this game taken to the next level... it's already so good and I can't wait to see what comes next.

I've given this game about 20 hours and so far it's been a solid piece of entertainment. I had fun taking story orders and tinkering with the extra jobs that would come along. I was already pretty experienced with cars and their workings before, but this game definitely taught me a few things. I then bought my first classic car in the game and fixed it up, painstaking process overall with money and tediously going through everything but that's what it's really like. There's a few things I haven't really enjoyed about this game though, and some of them really annoy me.

Things I disliked:

The game feels very.. empty in some aspects. You build a car, it finally runs and you test it out.. but after you're kind of left wondering "now what?" You either do the same thing over with it which is go to the track or sell it for profit and start another one.

The interior designing is strongly lacking, I was expecting loads of customization options but all you can really do is add different seats or a steering wheel. You can't change bench seat colours and you can't colourize the dashboard or carpetting. (disregard if you can, but if it's possible I haven't figured it out yet.) Paint and bodywork is beautiful and satisfying.

The driving mechanics and overall feel of the cars is very boring. Starting it up for the first time is very underwhelming, the sounds aren't the best, and you can't really do anything in the car. It'd be cool if it had more of a "My Summer Car" feel where you have to adjust things and manually operate the handbrake, use the radio etc. Driving is a massive bummer in this game.

Inaccuracy with classic cars. I know that making interchangeable parts for each individual car would be very time consuming and unnecessary from a gameplay standpoint but it doesn't make any sense how a car from 1954 has an electric fuel pump in the tank along with a modern fusebox. 

The entire motor being unable to turn over due to A MISSING CLIP. First motor rebuild I did I forgot to place one little clip on the distributor and the car just simply wouldn't start as a whole. I had to look up the problem to figure this out because everything else was perfect.

Not really any interactive aspects that let you tune up the car such as adjusting the timing of your distributor or tuning the carburetor. You just kind of slap it together and if all the parts are good it just works. This is a really significant downfall to me in a game about car repair and restoration.

Other than that, I found this game to be quite entertaining. I enjoyed tinkering with the cars coming in and out of the shop, figuring out their problems and solving them. It can be pretty educational at times too, great way to learn more about the fundamentals of a car and what makes it tick. Don't let my review spook you from buying this, I genuinely enjoyed it and found it very entertaining, just lacking in aspects that you'd expect more from in a game focused on cars. I feel that if this game mashed together with My Summer Car, it'd be one of the best games out there. All I can say is try it for yourself, I genuinely enjoy this game but it just has small little things I don't like.

Thank you for reading!

This is a fun game, and a great value for the money.  If you are at all interested in car restoration, car maintenance, learning more about the components of engines and putting cars together with relative ease, then this game will be fun for you.  The base game has some variety of vehicles but unfortunately, the variety of engines is still quite lacking, especially when you're building / restoring cars with the best possible engine so that you can maximize profit.  It can get monotonous and the garage company element of the game is very primitive - buy cars, restore them, and then sell them while taking story orders every now and then.  The DLCs add more variety to vehicles and add some to the gameplay, but there is just too much repetition without enough of a reason to replay (or keep playing).  Still, I feel it was a good experience until I finally got bored of it.

Decided to change my review to negative.

I enjoy playing this game, but there are some serious accessibility issues.

Key rebinding is not properly supported. For example, you can't remind mouse click actions. And the game requires you to HOLD left mouse button A LOT. My right hand hurts after playing this game for a while.

Plus there is no keybinding support for controllers AT ALL.

Another issue I found playing this game is that the game is too bright but there is NO brightness setting in game. My eyes were hurting before I realized what the problem was. I had to use AMD settings to turn down brightness for this game.

I love the game itself but it is the first game in a very long time that makes me physically uncomfortable to play. (And I've been playing a lot of games, almost every evening.)

It's 2023 (well the game was made two years ago) and I don't understand why a game would be shipped without these rather standard settings.

There are also some QoL problems. You have to remember a lot of information and sometimes it takes many clicks to switch between screens in order to do something while needing to remember what you specifically wanted to do. I guess you could argue this is a simulation game but once you do it a hundred times you'd wish the game makes it easier to do those things.

Oh another things - you can't change settings unless you are in the garage. If you are on the race track or junkyard and you want to change settings - no you can't until you return to the garage. I don't understand why the devs made the game this way...

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

[b]A Petrolhead's Delight[/b]

Rating: ★★★★★

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 has proven itself to be an absolute gem, not just for automobile aficionados, but for anyone seeking a rewarding and immersive simulation experience. This game's commitment to regular updates, rich variety, and engaging gameplay has turned it into an essential part of my gaming library, and it is bound to captivate anyone who dives into its intricately crafted world.

The developers' dedication to continuous improvement and content addition is commendable, ensuring that the gameplay remains fresh and engaging. Their commitment to constant updates is both apparent and appreciated. This constant evolution keeps me returning to the game, eager to explore the new features and improvements with each update.

Variety is truly the spice of life in Car Mechanic Simulator 2021. The assortment of tasks and orders on offer ensures that the gameplay never feels monotonous. The opportunity to restore dilapidated treasures from barns or junkyards into their former glory adds an extra layer of satisfaction to the game. This restoration aspect, akin to unearthing a hidden gem and polishing it to perfection, brings a gratifying sense of accomplishment.

Visually, the game is impressive. The graphics are well executed, creating a realistic and immersive garage environment. While some textures could use a bit of polishing, overall, the visual presentation is of high quality and adds to the game's authenticity.

The representation of car parts, while simplified, is well-implemented. Even though it doesn't delve into the complexities of every minute component, the level of detail strikes a perfect balance - maintaining realism while still being accessible and fun for players of all levels of mechanical knowledge.

In summary, Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 delivers a delightful experience that hits the sweet spot between challenge, realism, and fun. It's a testament to how a well-executed simulation game can captivate its players, offering continuous enjoyment through regular updates and a rich variety of tasks. Despite minor room for graphical improvements, this game is an absolute must-play and a shining example of its genre. Buckle up and get ready for an enjoyable ride!

Hi, this is my review of Car Mechanic Simulator 21. I have over 76 hours of hours in this game.

Car Mechanic Simulator 21 is a simulator that I have to say is still far from the real work of a car mechanic.  But since it is a game, it can somehow imitate the work.  Although in a very simplified and accelerated mode, but still... Thanks to this game, you can still learn something about this work (Names of parts, get a basic idea of ​​what is where and what all the cars have in them, and much, much more...).  But now to the simulator.  The simulator as such is interesting and if you are at least a little interested in the topic of cars, I think you won't be bored.  And even if you don't know what or how, the game is made so that even a person who doesn't know it can play it and have at least a little fun, and so from the beginning everything that needs to be changed is usually written and you can highlight it by pressing it to see where  It is.  The simulator starts with a tutorial that teaches you the basics such as changing the filters, changing the brakes, and this way you will gradually learn new and new things and how to repair/replace them. Later, when you are more experienced, it will no longer be a problem to replace the entire engine part by part or to replace the entire chassis. You can change almost anything in the game. From the engine to the body parts. The game has a system of improvements for points (quite similar to that in CMS 18), so the more you do on jobs, the more points you will have that you can spend on improving some ability (speed of tightening, speed of disassembly) but most importantly, you can open garage improvements  and add other assets such as a paint shop, a diagnostic track... Of course, this game is not all about completing tasks and being locked in a plot.  Maybe it looks like that at the beginning, but later when there is some money and some level, new places where you can do something will gradually open up (junkyard, auction network, speedway...) All these places are good for something.  At a junkyard, for example, you can get a car that can be yours quite cheaply, but the problem is that it is in a disastrous condition and it takes a lot of work and money to fix it.  But after renovation, these cars are usually sold with quite a large profit.  It depends on the type of car, etc... And if you have already made such a car, you can drive it to the speedway.  Or take the customer's car if it's driving and have it tested on the test track... It's up to you.  For those who bought the Drag dlc, they can even take their cars to drag races.

What i see negative in this game? The game receives a lot of paid dlcs, half of which are only remasters of old dlcs from CMS 18. Calculate the total amount for all dlcs, including Drag dlc and the latest tripledlc, so the amount is very high only for dlc for a game that will still get a sequel in a few years and the same thing again.

I hope I wrote the most important thing and that I helped someone.  I'm sorry for mistakes.  I'm writing this through a translator.  Bye!
