The good stuff: this game is fairly well-made, no complaints there. It is helpful for general purposes of learning cars.

However, DO NOT get this game to learn how to repair your car. I was really hoping to be able to learn how to do an oil change on the 2014 Corolla, but there's a bunch of problems the developers need to solve before it becomes useful in that way.

1) There is no Toyota Corolla in the game. The game sometimes uses aliases for some manufacturers (presumably a legal issue), and there are a few Toyota-copy cars apparently,  but not a Corolla. There's dozens of old muscle cars in this game, but the modern selection is severely lacking.

2) There is no way you can just...pick a car and work on it, I think. You have to encounter them in the course of the game, and then if you want to progress through the game, you have to get rid of the car. There may be some workaround to this by...going to auctions? Finding them in barns? Something; it's not intuitive or easily accessed.

2.5) The auto-shop the player works in has a big mechanical jack in it. Want to learn where your car's jack goes, and where to place the blocks? You're out of luck.

3) The procedure for changing oil on a car is to get a big ol' thingy and move it under your car and press a button. I do not own this thing, and it seems like it is one of those things that only real mechanics have. My dad, on the other hand, has a pump, a hose, and a series of bottles he uses to change his oil. I'd like to learn and practice that.

There are some other process issues. While clicking and holding is okay for unscrewing a part, I once removed a bumper by clicking on it. I don't think removing a bumper is quite that simple. These oversimplifications may make the game smoother, but at the expense of the educational value of the game.

Finally...why am I forced to work in this junk environment? It's probably realistic for a mechanic that's just starting out, but again, if you want to learn how to work on your car, doing so in a grimy setting seems real unnecessary -- especially when the tutorial has a nice, clean space where you can see everything.

So, all in all, a well-made game for what it wants to be; that may not be what you want it to be, though, and lacks the features that would make the game really useful.

Can't recommend this game enough. As much educational as it is fun. For beginners: Just be wary of money. Don't pour a ton of cash into your garage upgrades right off the bat as you'll need a bank to be able to complete some of the later, more expensive story jobs. if you've never played a Car Mechanic Sim game before, or last played the 2015 version, i greatly recommend playing CMS 2021. but if you have played CMS 2018, i personally feel 2021's entry is not enough of a step up to warrant repurchasing the game and all the DLCs.

there are a lot of really nice improvements to CMS 2021: the graphics and location design are much better than 2018's build, the addition of various new elements (fuse boxes, ECUs, fluid resevoirs) and everyday mechanic work (changing fluids) is nice, the new garage additions feel fitting and fun to mess with (car wash, brake lathe, outdoors areas, etc.) and the new auction house is a lot easier to use and somewhat more immersive than before.

but for the degree of grinding in both games (i have ~250 hours in CMS2018) to get upgrades, levels, new environments and the like, i feel there just isn't enough to work towards as a previous player of CMS2018. maybe if the controls were better optimized (i.e. middle mouse click & drag to orbit the camera instead of WASD), the UI was modernized, the grind reduced by maybe 10-15%, and maybe some more immersive mechanics (full 3d body repair, i.e. sanding, filling, repainting in full / wiring & dashboard deconstruction / even something simple like Power Wash Sim-style car washing, walking around and washing each part of the car using hitscanning) with something more than just a price tag and a cutscene. changes like that means a previous player like myself would get a bit more out of it.

again, if you've never played CMS, pick this up!! it's definitely the peak of the series as is, and with 2024/25 on the horizon, i'm excited for what devs have in store. but as a player who has been invested for 6 years, i just don't see enough of a jump between 2018 and 2021. take some extra time, maybe have a 4 or 5 year schedule, and use that time to advance each entry significantly past the previous ones. 

still love the series though. keep up the solid work, red dot!

Whats good about this game:
- detailed assembling and disassembling 
- there are at least 2000 unique parts for each part of a car, e.g. spark plug, rod cap, fuel rails, etc.
- there are like 50 different cars that you can choose from and renovate 
- you can repair components
- you can race your car when its finished
- you can test your car with the test track and the dyno
- plenty more features

whats bad about this game
- some (only a few) things are tedious and take a very long time, such as upgrading components to be 3 stars with 100 components or more, which can take roughly an hour with 1000 components, since I have like 15000 components (sandbox) this can obviously take a huge amount of time
- some processes are very simplified, such as welding your car to repair the body. all you do is click on  the welder, move it and then click ok and the game does the rest, which is nice from a time efficiency point of view but its not very satisfying, unless you have a lot of rust on your car which is pretty satisfying. same applies to the car wash feature and the paintshop
- idk i forgot

overall 9.5/10, i'm definitely going to continue playing and I really hope they release a car mechanic simulator 23/24 or something
Best Game Ever For Car Guys

Definitely not for beginners. Tutorial is about changing oil and tires, takes 5 min and that s all of it.
There are no explanations of the different parts of the car and their functions (or why you need to "balance" tire and what it is). I was here to learn and just got dropped there with unclear objectives and partial ways to complete them.

For example, on the first order you need to repair the "fuel pump". I spent 30 min to find none. I found the "fuel filter" which is just dangling in the air, this piece is not connected to anything. I haven't found a fuel tank either, which I thought could lead to the fuel pump. I went around the car, but didnt find any entry to put fuel into the car. Guess the game doesnt go into that kind of details... 
I started dismantling the whole engine but the more I removed the less I saw this pump and the less I wanted to put it back together if by miracle it was in the depth of the machine. So I asked for a refund.
I finally asked Youtube to enlighten me and a video in german showed me where the fuel pump (and tank) was hiding. Not fun.

I guess it s good for people who already are into mechanics (seeing the good reviews) and can skip the dummies' steps, but for beginners it s just not possible to complete the first order with so few pointers and explanations. 

If it s easier and less frustrating to find the solution on Youtube, I dont see the point in playing the game.

I was a huge fan of the older one. 

This one however is TOO BIG OF A GRIND. Every car has a ton of issues and most of the time is spent taking stuff a part and trying to find broken stuff. As a mechanic I can say this is not how things work. We listen for noises and get an idea of where the noise is and then isolate it that way. If I didn't do this I would spend all day on one car and make no money. 

Also almost every car requires you to drain and refill all the fluids. This again is not how things work. There is service life for fluids (except washer fluid). But in this game almost every car needs their brake fluid, power steering fluid, and coolant changed... Not to mention the stupid washer fluid requiring a drain and then fill. 

Also add an option like in Tank Mechanic Sim to add all missing parts to the cart

I feel like their is a lack of content so they just made all the story cars a PITA to extend the game play. I'm guessing all of the positive reviews are from those who like pointless grinds and have no mechanical experience.

My biggest regret was trying to give this game a fair chance after buying most of the DLC and wanting to like it and going out of the return window.

Really is a great game. It's an easy chill sim that you don't need to stress over. Just go at your own pace. My only criticism would be that its a little over-simplified. Understandably so, given that the average person who doesn't know much about cars can still jump in and have a great time. But it was a bit disheartening as someone with an automotive background to see how watered down some parts of it can be. It would be really cool to see more component models added so every car doesn't share the same handful of drivetrains, or that certain cars didn't have blatantly incorrect suspension setups, etc. 

Honestly a hardcore mode or something that really expands on the automotive experience would be really fun. After a while it sort of just turns into a repetetive "point and click" as youre doing pretty much the same process across all vehicles.

Would recommend regardless.

I've enjoyed playing this game, finished all the story missions, and mostly buying junkers. I either just get them running or fully restore them. I get the most satisfaction out of restoring complete junk to or near their former glory. I mostly avoid the the car show room, except for getting achievements. what's the point?
Now, as for actually restoring the cars, there is some issues.  All the operations involved in a vehicle are absent; electronics, vacuum, air intake, exhaust, fluid delivery are all only represented by various parts.  The actual operation of said part, where and how it's connected,  is only assumed. You're supposed to know this already, I guess. Some parts aren't even connected to their counterpart. There's no hoses, no wiring harness, cables, just the assumption that they work (somehow). I guess the brake master cylinder works via bluetooth, connected to the 4 wheels.  

Some other peeves  about this game are lack of engine animation, your shop is dirty as hell, but thankfully we learned how to clean, finally. Customers? Shop employees? No, no other NPC's in which to interact . I should have my own show room, in place of the current rent a space storage. Most of the engines sound really bad, and there should be more options for driving.
I give it a 7/10

The game is actually really accurate.

After playing the game for just 10 hours I could already pop the hood of my own car and point out pretty much everything and tell you what it was. Using the knowledge I used from this game alone I have already begun working on cars and hope to get an apprenticeship to become a mechanic in the future.

Overall I rate this game an 8/10 for learning the basics. Everything is easily accessible, accurate, and it's overall a pretty fun game. If you're new to cars like I am I highly recommend.

In the grim world of virtual car repair, Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 shines as a beacon of excellence. As an ardent fan of the franchise, I approached this installment with equal parts skepticism and excitement. And I am pleased to report that it did not disappoint! Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 has proven itself as a true successor to its predecessors, earning a solid four stars from this humble tech-priest.

First and foremost, the game's attention to detail is nothing short of commendable. From the engine bays to the interiors, every nook and cranny of the vehicles is meticulously recreated, allowing aspiring mechanics like myself to indulge in the intricacies of automotive engineering. The extensive range of car models available to tinker with is truly impressive, offering a delightful assortment of challenges for those seeking to test their mechanical prowess.

The gameplay mechanics of Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 are a testament to the developers' dedication. The intuitive interface and user-friendly controls make navigating through the various repair tasks a breeze. The addition of a comprehensive tutorial system ensures that even novices can gradually become adept grease monkeys, learning the ropes of the trade while enjoying the process. The satisfaction derived from troubleshooting and fixing complex issues is a unique thrill that the game captures flawlessly.

One aspect that truly sets Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 apart is its emphasis on authenticity. The game replicates the day-to-day challenges faced by real-world mechanics, incorporating a wide array of tools and equipment that accurately mirror those found in professional workshops. The inclusion of licensed parts and brand collaborations further enhances the immersion, creating an experience that is as close to reality as one can get without the grease-stained hands.

However, like any finely tuned machine, Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is not without a few occasional hiccups. While the game generally runs smoothly, there are instances of minor bugs and glitches that can momentarily interrupt the immersive experience. Additionally, the limited multiplayer options (Almost none) may leave some longing for more collaborative mechanics-based adventures. Nevertheless, these shortcomings are overshadowed by the game's overall brilliance.

It is quite satisfying when you buy a car from the junk yard, tear it down piece by piece and turn it into a brand new car.

This game has me absolutely hooked in, it's incredibly addicting and you lose track of time. It's a very great relaxing game, with good in-game music to listen to while repairing or building vehicles. Not only is it fun, relaxing and entertaining, but you also get to learn more about cars on the side, especially when you're constantly completing orders back-to-back. You can also build your own dream car from the ground up too, which is a great feature! The game has some really great workshop mods too that don't ruin the experience at all. I'd most definitely recommend this game to a friend, or anyone who enjoys anything related to cars. If you do and enjoy simulators, you should give this game a shot!

Over 100 hours of play invested at this point.

If you had the same love-hate relationship I did with CMS 2018, it was probably for the annoying method of shopping for parts and storing inventory.

I'm glad to say that the devs have remedied this by making the shopping list infinitely better to use eliminating the need to store way more parts than the game is optimised for.

The mod support is terrific and the drag racing DLC really added a whole new level of engagement and motivation for tuning vehicles.

I do wish there was native wheel support - that seems like a hell of an omission. Pair that with some auto cross or casual race events and you'd have yourself an incredible game - would be a great idea for a DLC but maybe that's something we can look forward to in the next iteration along with some more involved wiring, vacuum lines and all the other clearly non-existent components in cars in this  universe

Great game. Best assembly/disassembly of any I've played (vs House Flipper, Electrician Simulator). Even if cars aren't really your thing, if you like the House Flipper assembly, give this a try.

Callouts for the DEVs:

--It's inconvenient to press [Enter] and [Esc], as it requires taking a hand off either my mouse or ASWD. Please let me back our with a [Right-Click], and confirm with [Spacebar].

--My understanding is that the Welder is a once-and-done. Why then am I allowed to continue using it over-and-over, continuing to drain funds but accomplishing nothing? Please just throw a pop-up saying the frame has already been repaired.

--Please have license plates auto-populate. Even being able to type them in would be better. There is nothing fun about having to remember a license plate number, and then cycle around the wheels to get to every-single-digit...

5-Stars game...

Amazing. Addicting. Fun. 

2 criticisms (Still a 5-Star game)...

First, the game doesn't include or mention anything about the difficulty of actually timing an engine you have just built. You don't just throw everything in the engine and then the car starts. Every step in the assembly process requires lining up dots and making sure different timing markers are in the right location/degree. Not a big deal but the game just acts like you throw the parts into an engine however you want and then the engine just starts. Timing engines is an art and is one of the most difficult parts of engine building/swapping.

Second, no torque wrenches or regard for the fact that different bolts can require vastly different torque numbers. I don't know. Maybe it'd be annoying to have to add a step and have to set a torque wrench for every type of bolt, but I just think they could have included it SOMEHOW. Even a quick animation showing a torque wrench or something. Idk. Just a thought. You don't just use an impact tighten things arbitrarily in cars. Some people do and then the next time something needs to be worked on, it breaks the part or the bolt is stripped. Torque values exist for a REASON.

All in all, still a 5-Star game. I love this game. I love the auction system. I love the freedom to make money however the hell you want in whatever way you're clever enough to think of. Realism is obviously very good 9/10. Just a couple missed opportunities (in my personal opinion).

This game is essentially CMS 2018, The game in comparison to CMS 2018 Has very few major improvements besides graphics and a handful of in-game mechanics, although these are improvements the game still feels very repetitive and boring after a decent period of time, I think that considering this game is 3 years newer than CMS 2018 that there's few to little improvements to make it worth buying if you already have CMS 2018, if you don't have CMS 2018 though, you may find it good for a period of time.

I never had 45 hours in a game so quickly.
Took me like 5 days.
The game has great detail in parts and a lot of them and the graphics are absolutely fine for that.
Some things are a bit simplified of course, as you don't want to click 1 million times for assembling a car.
But it's fun and addictive and you actually learn a thing or two about cars.
You won't be able to build one yourself, but at least know where and what the important stuff is.
Even after I reached the state, where I had money to burn, I still continued enjoying just repairing and tuning cars.
It's rewarding and also very chill.
My hand gets destroyed from all that mouse clicking when I play hours and hours per day,
so I actually play with controller now. That works much better for me and prevents carpal tunnel.

The game has some usability issues which never got resolved.
Like, the shopping of missing parts is not really streamlined. It's a lot of clicking.
The shopping list is not that flexible and the controls for it clash with the shop controls.
If you are not cautious, you accidetnally delete something from the list
when you actually just wanted to go back to shop overview.

Another minus is: The minigames for certain actions like scrapping or repairing is completely
non-related to the games mechanics. They are just a little skill game.
And upgrading parts is generally a tedious waste of time (in an already tedious game).

You will inevitably make mistakes during assebly and if you are as dumb as me,
you will have to disasseble a V8 motor down to it's motor block again, when you are not paying attention,
because you forgot to insert ONE new piston ring and didn't reach the necessary condition threshold because of it.
But you will learn through pain...
And some error messages due to missing parts, wrong parts, or incomplete engines,
or engines that won't start are too generic.
You have no idea as a new player what you need to do to fix it or why a damper would not want to
go in there.
Telling me, that a motor is "not complete" after re-assembling it for 30 minutes is not exactly helpful.
Although, after you figure these things out, it's manageable.
(I just say: Check those d*mn clips on your ignition distributor and the ones on your air filter case...)
So overall, I'm a bit late to the party with this game, but I already got it's moneys worth out of it.
The DLCs are mostly recommended, except maybe for the Drag Racing DLC, which is overpriced for what is does.
I got all, except the Hot Rod (no interest in those) and the Drag Race one.
But play the demo, before you decide to buy DLCs.
Now, get rich, or lose your nerves trying.

What I write for this review is the experience I had with the game, everybody will experience things differently. This is my honest review if you don't like it well tough. Also no game is safe from a review whether its early access or full release, now onto the review.

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is a game all about fixing vehicles up. You can do jobs on AI vehicles or go to the junkyard & the auction to buy vehicles, fix them up & sell them. 

Vehicles: the vehicles in this game are awesome. The vanilla cars are from real cars but are not called their real names due to copyright issue but it doesn't hurt the game at all. The dlc vehicles are based on real cars with I think their real names as well. As I said these vehicles look amazing. 

Fixing: the base of the game is fixing the vehicles up for money & experience points. You can disassemble the vehicles & can ether fix the parts at workbenches or buy new. Some parts can be fixed & some have to be bought new. The only issue I encounter is some parts that can be fixed sometimes doesn't at the workbench. It feels like there is a limit to how many times you can repair parts before you have to buy new parts. 

Buying & Selling: you can sell old/new parts at any point. This also applies to the vehicles you buy, you can sell the vehicle at any point whether its at 10% fixed or 99% fixed. You can everything new except the cars. You can only buy new cars at the dealership but only have like 3 or 4 to buy.

Leveling UP: when leveling up in the game you can get a bigger garage, more lifts, more tools, cheaper prices & faster dissembling. Only issue is you continue to level up even after unlocking everything & nothing to spend the extra point on.

Coolest Feature: the coolest feature I like in the game is the shopping list system. In the previous game you couldn't add parts to a list to keep track but in this game you can add parts to buy to a list, go to the shop & click the part you cant to buy & i will pull up the part. 

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is by far the best of the series & I hope we can get a CMS game where we work on old vintage cars from the past or even a game where its futuristic cars. Ether way CMS 2021 is a solid 9/10 score & i highly recommend you pick this game along with the previous versions as well.

I am a 51 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 30 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he friended and invited me to watch him. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Simulator games these days are becoming a serious addiction for me. With Power Wash Simulator becoming one of the best zen-like time sinks I've ever played in my life (when it's out of Early Access I will do a full review) and my past addiction to time management games like Diner Dash I can easily play this game for hours on end with tunes in the background cranking out cars. There's not really a story here, obviously, but you start out from scratch with the most basic tools and a small garage, but over time you can expand, make repairing faster, and fix up cars from the ground up even.

You start out with just the basics. One lift, slow examination, mounting, and screwing skills. You start with the first of 30 story repairs by doing tire changes, fluid flushes, and basic repairs. The great thing about CMS is slowly getting you familiar with how cars work and break down. I felt like the game was rocket science at first and quickly got frustrated. What's a rubber bushing?! Where are they all?! Then I realized that all the bushings are tied to the suspension. You eventually learn each section of every car and will start building engines from the ground up and then entire cars. After about three or four hours I was expanding my garage by adding car washes, another lift, spending XP to make my skills faster, and adding things like a welder to get rid of rust on bodies.

Things get easier and faster once you unlock diagnostic tools like an OBD scanner, multimeter, and fuel and engine pressure tests. In the beginning, you basically have to take everything apart and look for the completely rusted parts as those are the ones needing replacement. The beginning cars will tell you what's wrong so you get the hang of how the gameplay loop works. Later on, every part will be undiscovered and it's up to you to diagnose, visually examine (it's an actual diagnostic mode), and know-how to spot fully worn parts. Sometimes you can take a car on a test track to get a wider diagnosis of what's wrong, then there's the test path for brakes and suspension. Eventually, you'll get the hang of what diagnostics work for each condition of a car. If the car won't start then you should use your examination mode first, then your OBD scanner and multimeter and fix those parts. If the engine fires up but won't drive then you need to do the other tests. Sometimes non of the tests will tell you what's wrong and you have to do exploration diagnostics.

There are other elements like a spring puller for shocks, tire separator, and balancer, a brake disc lathe, and you can do a small minigame to repair parts that aren't completely destroyed, of course, once you unlock all these tools. You can even do headlamp adjustments and alignments. It's fun changing fluids, screwing in parts, and discovering new engine types with more pieces than before, but after you finish the story all that's left are random repairs (which are quicker than story missions) and visiting the junkyard and auction to rebuild cars and sell them for more money to turn around and buy more cars, but what's the appeal in that? Driving the cars on the track is really generic and boring, and the fun part of the game is the mechanic part. I don't want to collect cars really. Once I upgraded and bought all the expansions there wasn't anything left to do.

After about 20 hours I could build any car with my eyes closed, and this is my main concern with CMS. The individual car systems are limited in scope. Yes, there are many engine types, but they all go together basically the same just with different parts and varying sizes. It was fun to build an engine on the stand and lower it into the car. I had fun restoring several cars and repainting them or giving the car performance parts to stick on the dyno. However, if it's not for a repair I didn't feel any satisfaction. Once you rebuild a few cars you experience the most challenging part of the game. There were a few issues early on in which you can get stuck with no money if you start buying up too much. You need to grind repairs until you get around 30,000 credits and can rebuild and sell a simple car from the junkyard to give you your first serious payment.

The other issue is that everything is canned. All animations and movements and actions. This isn't Surgeon Simulator or Cooking simulator. There are no hands you control in real-time. When you click apart there's an outline of where it needs to go. You hold the mouse button down and the part appears and so do the screws. You hold the mouse down on all the screws and you move on to the next part. It's essentially like building Legos. The overall longevity outside of the story missions will determine how much you get out of these limited systems within the cars and various small mini-games. It becomes redundant and almost boring after so long when the entire reaches its peak early on.

What's here is a satisfying and fun simulator for at least 20-30 hours. You will want to grind the story missions, unlock everything, and experience everything at least once. Restoring cars from just the frame is fun, but I also would have liked more exterior customization. It's very limited to just doors, windows, hood, trunk, lights, mirrors, and that's it. There's also almost no satisfaction from just buying cars, restoring them, and keeping them to race on a dull track, or selling them for money that isn't really needed anymore once you unlock everything.

Graphics are greatly improved over 2018.  I like the new balancing and part repairing system.  It's a little more complex than it was in 2018, but it makes it so you actually have a bearing on how well something is repaired.  This game is a fun and simple time sink for those of us that just want to click things and 'vedge out'.  It's not a simulator. It's not going to teach you how to repair your car. It's just good mindless fun.
I haven't figure out everything yet, like i started the scrapping stuff but haven't gone back to it.  I like the upgrades and customization you can do to your garage space.
I have done any driving either, because I just didn't care for it back in 2018, I haven't bothered.
Really the only thing I don't like, so far, if I had to nitpick, would be the shopping list and store stuff.  I feel like it is not very intuitive and a bit clunky.  I do like that you can search fro parts right from your shopping list, but I'd like to have a way to check off the items I got without removing them from the list, as well as adjust the number of the item I need.  I'd also like the shop to set the sizes of stuff like tires and rims for me if I buy the item by search from the shopping list, or at least give me a spot where I can make a note of the size I need so I have it on the purchase screen.
That's all I have for now, just about 10 hours in.  If I find anything else I want to rave or rant about, I'll update.  Hope this help anyone on the fence.

This simulator is a phenomenal educational device and an addictive pass time for those who enjoy performing repetitive, complex tasks with many positive reinforcements in the form of CR (in game money), a clean and organized garage, and, most importantly, a collection of beautiful cars! These cars can even be driven around town or taken to the local race track to test their high end performance with very realistic emulation for how the vehicles would perform in the real world.

Driving the vehicles most certainly takes a back seat to the process of taking the vehicles apart, repairing what can be repaired, replacing what cannot, then reassembling the vehicle to its factory glory or even tuning it to be a superior version of its original design. While the vehicles in the base game are all fictitious (generally based on a real world car, or a mash-up of multiple real world vehicles), the parts you'll interact with in game are representative of the parts used in real world vehicles and will help the player come to an intermediate-to-advanced understanding of the inner workings of their vehicle.

It is this familiarity with vehicle mechanics that in my opinion elevates this game to higher education level of value. Unquestionably I will have my children play this (or the latest version of this game) when they are becoming old enough to drive. I can think of few more effective ways to help them understand the 2-ton death machines they'll be operating. Perhaps they'll even develop a love for the processes they learn in game and dedicate themselves to the craft. Even if they don't choose to be a mechanic, the game will offer them practice in operating a business with substantial initial investments before becoming profitable. 

In summation, this game is among the most fun experiences I've had in the process of deep learning and highly recommend it for both meditative pleasure and personal education.

TLDR;  The game doesn't represent how a car mechanic and general mechanics work, and is not ''highly realistic'' as advertised. 

As a professional car technician for years, this really insults me.
It's not realistic at all.  Couple of examples:
- Head gaskets doesn't exist in this game. Neither do head bolts.
- All cars use the same brake pads, and all cars have disc brakes.
- Toothed timing belts doesn't have teeth.
- Engine hoses and wiring doesn't exist in this game.
- Changing fluids by sucking it out with a pump? That's called a scam.
- Parts can't be accessed from the underside and vice versa when they clearly can.
- Parts are bolted on with unrealistic oversized bolts, and with too few bolts. (i.e: power steering pump has one bolt)
- Car lift has only two positions; bottom or fully up. And not the recommended half position.
- Compression test can't be done if the engine doesn't start.
- Bolts inside the engine are rusted and can be loosened with some WD40.
- Pricing of parts doesn't make any sense. 
- You have to pay a fee if you spill oil on the floor instead of just cleaning it up.
- And a lot more stuff like this.

I really love this game. The detail on the models is great, the graphics are alright, the gameplay is fun... It's a good game. However I have some major complaints:

1. Lack of engine options - some cars only have one or two engine options, I want more.

2. Horrible engine sounds - the engine sounds in the game are absolutely atrocious and are the same three reused for every engine. When I spend hours refurbishing a car, and decking out the engine, I want to hear the fruits of my labor, not some CopyRightFreeEngineSound.mp3 garbage.

3. Awful vehicle physics/handling - I understand the focus of this game is not the driving, but the driving mechanics feel like they belong in a mobile game, a little more effort would be great.

4. No steering wheel support.

5. The DLCs are often very bare bones and don't do much that a mod can't.

6. A lot more that I am forgetting right now.

Basically, it's a great game, if you love cars, it's worth it. However, there are a *lot* of problems. Your decision.

First thing first. As many other sim/build type games, this is as repetitive as can be. If that's not your thing, move along.

Educational value is basic. You will learn basic parts of cars and how they go together, but you will not learn how a combustion engine actually works. Or gearbox, Or turbo, or etc. The parts available are also quite simplified which is both a good thing and a bad thing. Good thing is it keeps the game easy to approach but on the flip side once you are comfortable with it you kind want a bit more detail. In that regard 2021 is a small step forward from previous version as it adds a few things basic liquids and more electrical components. No wires or hoses which I would personally really like to see. Visually the game looks decent enough but will not win any realism awards. Broken parts are just rusty, there is no other indicator or different ways to break. "Fixing" things or doing assembly tasks are done via simple mini-games which is ok I guess but also could use little bit more complexity. Scrapping/repairing in particular are just endless clickety-click. You do that a lot though, so it needs to be very fast to do which is a tough equation to crack...fast task that isn't brainless?

Modding community is great and definitely helps with more variety, allthough new official DLC also come about every now and then to add more things/engines/cars.

I've played the game for over 200 hours, gotten every achievement, and I've learned absolutely nothing about building cars irl. Thanks CMS 2021! 

Memes aside, there are some really easy quality of life additions devs can do to make the game WAY less painful. Even without taking away from the "realism" they're going for. 

1. Uncap the limit on the amount of parts you can buy at once. A limit cap of 50 is too low. In total to get the Trader achievement you need to buy like, 900 Rubber Bushings. (Not exaggerating) When you can only buy 50 at a time, it's annoying. 
2. Make it so you can type in the number of items you need in the "Buy" menu, instead of having to click the tiny little arrow to scroll one number at a time. If you need exactly 18 bushings for a car, it would be nice to just click and type "18".
3. Make an option for the window tinting mechanism to "Tint All Except Windshield". Tinting every window black, then having to go back in and clear the windshield for more money doesn't make sense. Doing each window individually is annoying as well. 
4. This one kind of takes away from the realism aspect I guess. But when you add a tire to your shopping list, it would be amazing if the dimensions of the tire were attached with it. You could even make it a skill you have to unlock or something. You're finished unlocking stations and skills WAY before you hit level 50 anyway. You could easily add more. 

Overall: You will absolutely not learn anything you can use irl from this sim. Aside from maybe learning the names of parts in an engine. Simulators in general are pretty cozy. This one doesn't fail to deliver that. Solid sim.

I've played this enough now to compare it to 2018, which some people may prefer over 2021. In my experience though, 2021 is a total overhaul full of improvements over 2018. The garage is way less claustrophobic with a neat outside area, there are many QoL improvements in general, and most of the new additions to cars and mechanics are simply better. It also just looks better, too. Now, there are mods that basically double the features and improve on the rest, but so far I didn't feel bored enough to spice my game up that way. Adding new cars via the workshop just works for me. But just know that the game is heavily moddable in any of its aspects, as well.

Title: Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 - A Satisfying and Realistic Simulation Game for Car Enthusiasts

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is a simulation game developed by Red Dot Games, where players take on the role of a car mechanic and run their own repair shop. As a fan of cars and simulation games, I was excited to try out Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 and see how it compared to other simulation games in the genre.

The gameplay in Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is engaging and realistic, with a range of tools and equipment to use to diagnose and repair cars. The game features a range of car models to repair, from vintage to modern, with each car requiring different parts and repair procedures. The game's difficulty level is well-balanced, and the game offers multiple modes to extend the gameplay.

The graphics in Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 are stunning, with a range of detailed and immersive environments that capture the atmosphere of a real-life car garage. The car models are also well-done, with a range of accurate and detailed designs that make each car feel unique.

The sound design in Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is well-done, with a range of realistic sound effects associated with repairing cars. The game's music is also well-done, with a range of upbeat and engaging tracks that match the game's mechanics.

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 does not have a traditional story, but the game's narrative is revealed through the player's experiences in running their own repair shop. The game's simulation approach allows for a unique and personalized storytelling experience.

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 has excellent replay value, with a range of car models to repair and a variety of parts and repair procedures to experiment with. The game also features a sandbox mode, which allows players to experiment and test out different repair techniques.

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is a satisfying and realistic simulation game that is perfect for car enthusiasts and fans of simulation games. The gameplay is engaging and well-balanced, and the graphics and sound design are stunning. The game's simulation approach allows for a unique and personalized storytelling experience. Overall, I highly recommend Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 to anyone looking for a satisfying and engaging simulation game. I give Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 an 8.5 out of 10 and consider it one of the best simulation games available for car enthusiasts.

This is definitely not a game for a casual player. It is very complex with many different parts to pay attention to, remember, and customize. The level of detail and customization blew me away- it seems perfect for a person who wants a realistic car game. 
For me personally, it was too much to remember, learn, and pay attention to. I work on my car irl since I autocross, and wanted to use this game to learn a bit more. It's not quite detailed enough for that, while having a pretty complicated menu system that could probably be more intuitive if things were interactive instead of using the multiple circle menus with no labeling what each icon means until you hover over it. Very steep learning curve. 
I do appreciate the attention to detail, how each car seems quite correct in most ways to its original model, down to the suspension parts. I can tell people who love cars made this game, so hats off to you. I simply don't have the attention span for it XD
And for those who like it, enjoy. It seems pretty darn impressive, but by the end of the tutorial, I was pretty bored and a tad confused at how much there was to remember. I feel genuinely sad that I wasn't into it, since I'm such a car person. I recommend that you try it at least, the detail really is impressive.

These are off-putting, immersion breaking and have no place in game. Some how, in 2022, they still have not figured out how to make the work areas open and seamless.......so we get phasing through doors and station porting. This is a buy on sale but don't expect a full simulation experience.

Comparison to CMS 2018:

Graphics: More Detailed
Textures and lighting are way better, rust maps and reflections have increased resolution. Makes looking at the parts and cars more pleasing and realistic.

Audio: Better
The core sounds like mounting and screwing are the same as 2018. The engine sounds are much more realistic compared to the whiny and screechy 2018 engines. The V10s and V12s now sound like engines instead of dying cats.

Gameplay: Similar
The gameplay loop is very close to CMS 2018. The orders come in and are completed the same way. More variety from the new vehicles and engines added to this version. New features include the ability to randomly determine a certain number of parts' damage in different sections of the vehicle (engine, rear center suspension, unsprung suspension), and move vehicles to other locations regardless of installed suspension and wheels, such as from a lift to the garage entrances to the paintshop, but they will sit on bricks.

Progression: More Expensive
The examination tools that you start with in 2018 now have to be bought, albeit for low prices. The garage expansions and workbenches have to be bought, and in the case of the paintshop, have different tiers that include new features. Skill points are only used to decrease the amount of time spent examining, removing, placing, and screwing parts, with each rank needing 1+ what you used on the last rank. There are six skills that can be upgraded, and the total skill points needed to unlock them all is 126, 21 per tree. Luckily, the number of points gained per level up increases by one at levels 4, 7, and 10.

Shop Layout: More Realistic
The area around the shop has been fleshed out and given an environment. The dyno has been given its own building, and the paint shop and test path have their own building as well. All of the workbenches and the warehouse have been moved into their own room in the main garage. Number of lifts has been reduced from 3 to 2 unfortunately. Two new additions include a salvage bench and a car wash. Moving between the buildings does not cause lag or loading screens.

Auction: Much Improved
The auction system is much better, where 2018 had 6 cars per visit and they had to be bidded on in order. 2021 lets you choose between complete cars for more money and salvage cars with varying levels of damage and missing parts for cheap. They can be chosen in whatever order you want and have more variety with more cars per visit. Your Steam friends are also included as other bidders at auctions instead of generated names.

Part Repair: More Tedious
You have to play a minigame for every part, and level of repair is based on how well you do in the minigame. Makes reusing parts a pain.

Paintshop: More Choice
Paints have different options for finishes and choices for factory colors with more upgrades. Number of decals have been increased.

New Features:

Salvaging: Aggravating
Every part is given a star rating based on the number of times it has been upgraded. This works similar to the quality system in 2018, where some parts found are better. Performance parts get a power boost from upgrading, and engines without 3 star performance parts can't make the same horsepower numbers as typical store bought 2018 parts. Upgrades require ridiculous amounts of scrap when salvaged parts give 1-2-3 scrap based on how well you did in the minigame for each part salvaged. Around $10,000-$12,000 worth of junkyard parts will yield around 1,000 scrap. Only worth making extremely high horsepower engines.

Carburetor and ECU Tuning: Take It or Leave It
The tuning system is based on whether you install performance carburetors or a performance ECU. The higher the stage on the ECU, the more options you have to boost your performance. Tuning is affected by moving individual bars or circles and managing the dip in power that changing one setting causes. +1 on one bar causes -1 on the other bars and vice versa in the range of -2 to +2. Partly skill, partly RNG. If you take the time to get the maximum percent, with a stage 3 ECU, you can get a +10% to your total horsepower, but a stage 3 ECU costs $10,000.

Overall: 4.4 of 5
A very meditative gameplay loop and all in all, a great improvement to CMS 2018.

Amazing game!I love how this series expanded and evolved. 2014 was cool and unique. 2015 was a massive improvement, making it feel like a whole different game. 2018 was even better, especially with all the DLC content to add variety. 2021 does the same thing. There is so much more added in. Details and parts that were missing before are added in. The additional testing options in the test path and the new areas of the car (fuse boxes and fluids) make it even more fun. Another complaint I recall people having in the older games was that there were no stuck bolts, but they even finally added that in.One of the best features is the grind..some people may not like it but I prefer to play these games in the hardest difficulty setting and in the previous games, it was way too easy to make money. This game makes the grind a lot harder which makes upgrades like discounts at the shop, significantly more useful. Saving up to buy something important or to build a nice car is really a treat. You really get a sense of accomplishment when you complete a project.Cons: There are a few.-You can no longer enter examination mode and individually inspect a part. Instead you stand outside the car and select a group/region and it auto inspects the area. I find that annoying. It saves time I suppose but it is frustrating if you forget which specific part you were intending to replace.-As with the previous titles, the sound effects and UI noises are truly great but the car engine sounds are pretty bad. I don't mind so much though since I don't care for the driving. I have actual racing sims for that.-I also miss the 2018 style garage. The one in this game isn't as nice to look at and I don't enjoy the layout as much. Not a big deal but still a con to me.Overall, I respect this developer so much now after having played all through this series and watching it evolve. I HIGHLY recommend this title to anyone that enjoys simulation games or cars in general.

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is the ultimate car mechanic experience! With eight years of experience under my belt, I thought I had seen it all. But boy was I wrong! The cars that people bring in for repairs these days are straight out of a scrap yard. But that's where the fun starts!

One memorable experience was when Anna Power came in with her old jalopy. The car was in such bad shape that I wasn't sure if it would ever run again. But, as they say, where there's smoke, there's fire! So, I got to work, starting with the exterior cleaning. I'm talking a full-on scrub, polish, and wax! Then, it was time to tackle the engine. After replacing the busted parts and tuning it up, it purred like a kitten.

But the fun didn't stop there! Anna wanted the interior of the car to sparkle too, so I gave it a thorough cleaning. The amount of gunk that came out of the seats was unbelievable. But after a few hours of scrubbing and cleaning, the interior was as good as new!

Finally, it was time to hand the car back to Anna. She was thrilled with the job I had done, and even left me her phone number in case I ever wanted to grab a drink. Overall, Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 takes the cake as the best car mechanic simulator yet, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a fun and challenging experience.

Fun game. I've played it lots, and liked it enough to get the DLC.  It's more game than simulation, but even so I have learned a lot about car suspensions and engine parts. 

The game is very light on the internal parts of a car. Don't expect to work on blower motors, center consoles,  or dashboards. Body work seems like an afterthought. Fenders and bumpers just pop right off! There's no work to remove them, no bolts, no grommets, nothing. They just slide right off! There are no cowlings. Wipers are displayed, but can't be changed or worked on. Wiper motors, wiper arms, wiper wiring, none of them are there. Indeed, there are no hoses and wires. The economy is very simple, so it is fairly easy to make money.

On the plus side, I have enjoyed playing the game. Also, I have learned a lot about engines and suspensions. The normal and easy levels show hints and "ghost" parts, to allow for non-mechanics (like myself) to know where parts can and should go. This greatly reduces frustration. Even with that, the first few cars I worked on, I was wondering where things were. I needed to replace a camshaft, and I had no idea what a camshaft was. It took me a little bit to find it. Then people started asking for "tune ups." To me, that meant adjusting the engine to idle and run smoother. In the game, that means buying parts from the Tune-Up shop!

I have played this for almost 80 hours now. I liked it enough that I purchased the DLC, which is something I almost never do. So I recommend the game.

I now know a lot more about what pieces are involved in the brakes, the engine, the exhaust sytem, etc.  I'm not going to be able to take my car apart and put it back together, but I can at least have a conversation with the mechanic now without sounding totally stupid.

Second, I wanted a fun easy little game I could play with my 4 year old son.  He loves it and regularly asks to play the car game so he can pick out an old beater from a barn and we can put it together and race it around the track.  Memories made!

8/10  It might not be as hyper realistic as we want, but it does scratch the itch when you want to work on a car.  Plus you never worry about losing your 10mm socket.  Having bent some valves and bodged up timing on a real car many years ago, it's nice to play around on an engine without fear of destroying another car.

I began a new game on expert for the first time and realized that I don't need the assistive highlighting.  That's a win!

Don't expect to take the family car apart and put back together again.  There isn't nearly enough level of detail or realism for that.  So, folks, if you aren't already a mechanic don't go trying to convince your significant other that you need a multi-rack of tools from Snap-On just yet.

[b] Rev Up Your Engines: Experience the Thrill of Car Repair in Car Mechanic Simulator 2021[/b]

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is an immersive and engaging game that lets players experience the thrill of running their own car repair shop. With its realistic graphics, detailed car models, and variety of repair jobs, players will feel like they are truly working on real cars. The game's intuitive controls and helpful tutorials make it easy for both new and experienced players to jump right in and start fixing cars. Overall, Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is a great choice for anyone who loves cars and enjoys a good simulation game.

I'm not a mechanic and do not enjoy working on cars. I just don't care for the grime and grease and mess. Recently, due to inflation, I've had to do a few things myself like a brake job on my F250. Mechanic said $450 and I found the brake pads for $50. So I splurged and got the $75 pads. Online video on how to do the job was 6 minutes long so I was a bit disappointed when the job took me 8 hours! But the satisfaction at having done it myself made me more open to trying this game.

I have to say, seeing a restoration without all the grease, grime, and muck is far more enjoyable. I've played over 100 hours and I am still having fun!

The boys had their fun with God of War Ragnarok, now it's time for the men

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is a highly realistic simulation game that puts players in the shoes of a car mechanic, tasked with repairing and restoring a wide range of vehicles. With a huge variety of cars, parts, and tools to work with, the game offers an immersive and challenging experience for players who love the world of cars and mechanics.

One of the best aspects of Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is the attention to detail. Every car and part is accurately modeled, and players must use real-world techniques and tools to diagnose and repair problems. The game also offers a deep and engaging career mode, where players can manage their own garage, buy and sell cars, and build their reputation as a top mechanic.

The graphics and sound design are also impressive, with realistic engine sounds and detailed car models that allow players to see every part of the vehicle. The controls are intuitive and easy to use, making it easy for players to dive into the world of car mechanics and get to work.

Overall, Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is a must-play game for anyone who loves cars and mechanics. It offers a realistic and immersive experience that will satisfy even the most discerning fans of the genre. Whether you're a professional mechanic or just a casual fan, this game is sure to provide hours of entertainment and challenge.

This simulator is a really good entry for those who have wondered if being a auto mechanic is what they want to do. It is a simplified perspective of what one may expect when diving deeper in the heart and bones of the automobile. You will learn the layout of the different engines and the various types of suspensions system for each kind of car you will encounter in the real world. I can say with 100% confidence that my car in RL resembles the version portrayed in this game.

To be clear, it's a 'simplified' version of what you will see in real life. There's no wiring harness, fuel lines, brake lines, you don't need to accurately fix timings, and sometimes the assembly/disassembly order is not realistic. But, this does not take away from the level of detail portrayed in this game. If anything (if this is for you) it will further your interest into auto mechanic to the next level.

This simulator strikes me as particularly realistic, because half of the time in-game is spent unscrewing things using gallons of WD-40, and the other half is spent on searching for compatible replacement parts in a simulated online store.
I still had plenty fun, though, I appreciate the large variety of different engine designs implemented in the game, and overall scope of repairs the player does to cars. Highly detailed 3D models make disassembly and reassembly an great exercise in technical curiosity.
However, that's pretty much all there is to do. After 20 hours I feel like I've seen almost everything the game has to offer, all I could do now is to optimize my workflow further and make bank.
I found the career mode difficult at times, because in-game money is sometimes tight, and story missions do not tell you in advance how much money you're going to need to complete them. This, combined with a single save file, means it's relatively easy to get completely stuck by mistake, and recovering requires grinding boring cookie-cutter generative side missions. Some gameplay elements are never explained, e.g. the purpose of upgrades, which makes for fun exploration, but ends up being confusing at times, and I needed to read guides to learn which upgrades I need to do a particular type of repair.
Story missions are kinda weird, where the storyline description often does not match the damage on the car, but you're not getting this game to read customer stories.
Overall a fun experience. And if you happen know all about how OHV and OHC engines differ in terms of which parts are susceptible to most wear, you should enjoy this game a lot.

After playing Car Mechanic 2018 for 100 hours, I decided to get this game when it released. There are some improvements but also some problems. First, lets cover improvements. Graphics are a step up from 2018, and as well as this, the repairs are a lot more in depth, with the addition of fluids besides oil, and yet more parts to keep track of. For people who like mental puzzles in video games, this is perfect. Plus, its accurate for people who are into cars. However, I have several problems. First, the game doesn't run that great on low-end hardware. I have a decent gaming laptop, with an i5-9300h, GTX 1650, and 24GB ram, and I can only run it on medium settings at 50~ fps. Second off, if you choose not to purchase dlc, the car roster is still fictional, which can annoy hardcore car guys like myself. Finally, although I like the complexity, its definitely not for everyone. Overall, I recommend the game, but I'll admit its not for everyone, and I'd only truly recommend it for people willing to put up with some of these issues.

NO, because its UI is gets to be the "design pain" that you get on real cars trying to reach that one part... the developers don't play their own game, otherwise they would understand the frustrations of having to :

Paint parts one-by-one-by-one... not having small parts stack (got 20 rubber bearings 2 pages in the inventory, which you cannot go from 1 to 20 without having to go through all the other pages. 

Somethings are right click others are left click, some get the command wheel others don't, some click on picture some click on button... ugh of course there are the keyboard commands that kind of help.

Some cars don't list the engine they take, just a picture of one of two engines... and it only takes one.

The mini games are kinda cool for the first 5 minutes, but when you got 100s of parts to scrap, you start to not care. Not to mention it will take 1000s of parts to get a 3 star engine, and parts give 1-3 (some 4 or 5), if you play the mini game. You will upgrade your parts to 3 star once and never do it again.

Some things you put together before hand, which is cool (shocks, tires), but others you have to click multiple times when installing... suspension arms, pistons, etc...

I played one character for 40 hours, only got to level 17ish... and am really annoyed with the speed a which you mount parts and screws, sure you can speed them up - but still gets very old very quick.

The car designs are not really that different, there are maybe 3 types.

If you are asking yourself if this game will teach you anything about mechanics? It will teach you the parts of an engine, like looking at a picture - otherwise not much else to learn about cars

So 50/50, if you are a car builder or like clicking and holding A Lot!

So, for the folks who are already fans of the CMS series, if you're wondering if you should pull the plug and upgrade to CMS 2021, my short answer is "yes." If you have even a passive interest in working on cars - even if you don't do it in real life - this will be a good simulator for you.

Now, time to dig into the details.

First of all, the overall premise is pretty simple: you're a mechanic. You have a garage. You work on cars. What type of work you do, or how you do it, is entirely up to you. Just work in your garage and have fun tearing apart cars and fixing them.

You start out as a standard mechanic, taking on orders from customers. They'll send in their car with all its problems - bad breaks, or poor shifting, or noisy acceleration, or whatever the case may be. Early on, you're cash-poor and inexperienced, so it takes you quite a while to unscrew the bolts, and every little bit of change helps. As you gain experience, you "level up" and can increase your skills on a skill tree, and your progression is up to you - you can upgrade your bolt screwing speed, get discounts from the shop, increase your ability to diagnose things, etc. As you gain cash you can buy expansions for your garage, from extra car lifts to portable diagnostics tools to even a dyno. Keep grinding those customer car jobs!

As you begin to get a little bit of cash built up, you can begin to expand your activities into other fields, such as buying old junkers to restore to new, or even buying high-end cars so you can tune the heck out of them to increase their performance to frankly almost unrealistic levels. You'll find yourself doing all kinds of activities car-fixing/tuning related.

There is a bit of a rinse-repeat element to this game. Although there is plenty of variety, it IS basically the same thing - tear cars apart and put them back together. For people who are into this kind of game, in no way does that "rinse/repeat" element get in the way of having fun. I logged I don't even know how many hours in 2018, and have already logged 42 hours in this iteration.

For fans of 2018, I CAN say that there is a WORLD of new cars, parts, engine layouts, and overall options. There were plenty of parts in 2018, for sure, but I can now scroll through just page after page of JUST RIMS, let alone other parts. There are so many different parts now that the devs actually split the standard car parts into two different stores - mechanical parts and electrical parts. (For example, the spark plugs and ignition coils can no longer be found in the same store as, say, Idle Roller B's.) That says nothing about the tuning parts store, the interior parts store, and all the rest. If you were a fan of how many parts were in 2018, you're going to be in heaven in 2021. (Also thank GOD for all the different engine layouts in 2021. I was beginning to know the layouts in 2018 like the back of my hand.)

This version crushes a few of the old annoyances from 2018, and completely misses other annoyances. It's an overall improvement, but I wish a few of the old "ugh"'s had been solved.

One such example of a miss is that "omg I put the rubber bushing in the wrong spot" issue. If you've played 2018, you KNOW what I'm talking about. Let's say you're fixing a car and the owner wants at least 50% or better parts put in on the repair. You find out that this rubber bushing over here in spot X is at 48%, but it's not listed as one of the problems. This rubber bushing over HERE, though, in THIS SPOT (spot Y) is at 7% and is listed as one of the problems. You buy a brand new one. You forget where the problem was and forget to "highlight" it and install the brand new one in spot X, and the 48% one in spot Y.... and the overview states you have not fixed the problem. You know, because the brand new one was not put in EXACTLY THE RIGHT SPOT. So now you get to tear back down and put the exact same rubber bushings (48% and 100%) in different spots, which magically solves the issue. UUUUUGH. Yes, that is still a thing.

There are some things that are no longer "a thing," however. You remember how in 2018, you would have a bad part that had not yet been identified, and you would tear the entire engine down searching for that ONE STINKING PART that just could NOT be found? ...And then you'd find out it was "Clip B" on the air filter cover? You just stripped the entire engine down to the engine block and Clip B was the "problem"!? Yeah, I haven't seen that so far in 42 hours of gameplay. If "Clip B" (or some other such tiny issue) is a problem, it's going to be part of a larger problem - such as the air filter or something.

Another thing I LOVE... is the new "list search" feature. You old 2018 fellows know the pain of creating your shopping list and buying. Make sure to make up your list in alphabetical order... then go through the entire part list, buying item after item, making sure to remember your spot. It can be QUITE tedious indeed. 2021 allows you to immediately search the store for items on your shopping list, making buying all of the parts a fairly painless process. And you can edit your list on the fly, as well - after you buy a part, delete it and move on to the next. Huge time saver!

Next is the fact that a lot of equipment interaction is no longer either simply a "wait it out" process or a random process. For example, to "fix" a part in 2018, you.... clicked the part at the work bench. Then there was a certain percentage chance that you'd fix the part or damage it further. Nothing other than random dumb luck. Once you upgraded enough the repair was pretty much certain, but still, at that point you're just clicking parts again and again.  CMS added little "mini games" for things such as this. Ok, so the mini games are kind of dumb and often give very little of a feel that you're actually doing anything... (For example, at the work bench, to fix a part, a little slider goes left and right really quickly, and you try to time it just right to land on the "fix" bar to fix it)... but it DOES break the monotony of click-click-click-click-click that all just depends on dumb luck. So while I could envision better, more relevant mini games, this is definitely a step in the right direction. (Some of them are a LITTLE more relevant, such as the "alignment" thing for headlights and wheels. Still not very complicated, but at least related to the task at hand.)

For the equipment that DOESN'T have a mini game, though, the waits aren't nearly as excruciatingly long - and you all from 2018 know what I'm talking about, with the spring compressor, tire changer, and wheel balancer. Yes, they do their jobs much more quickly.

I do like the addition of the brake lathe. I don't know how many brake discs I simply scrapped in 2018. It's nice to be able to re-use these  now :-)

There are other things such as the new "scraps" thing which I haven't made extensive use of yet. I'm sure I will at some point, but I've read it doesn't have a ton of impact for the effort, so who knows. I'll find out some other time.

ALSO, the driving handling is significantly better. I don't know if I was just doing something wrong in 2018, but I really didn't care for driving the cars much because it just felt so dumb compared with other driving simulators. 2021, I still get a "weird" feeling from the driving, but it's MUCH better, and I don't feel nearly so frustrated trying to control the vehicle.

Overall, this one is a solid "yes." I was on the fence for SO LONG, worrying that 2021 would only be a MARGINAL improvement upon 2018, but I was wrong. It's not the difference between night and day - it's still basically the same game with some great improvements - but I'm absolutely satisfied for having pulled the trigger. It IS the better of the two, ESPECIALLY given all the new parts and cars and sheer VARIETY of things to do, on top of an overall graphics improvement. If you're wondering if it's worth it to upgrade from 2018 to 2021, SOLID YES FROM ME

If you've never played one of the CMS games, you are sure to have a great time relaxing and playing this one. It's the best in the series so far and has a decent gameplay loop. That being said, I'm not recommending it for people who own 2018. 

In 3 years, this studio has not managed to add more than a simple "time click" mini-game to the core gameplay. They straight up imported most of the cars from the previous game with only the most minor tweeks. The XP system is still far too grindy and the perk system is almost an exact copy from 2018. 

I really lost some respect for this company when I saw a main story job that was almost verbatim from a main story mission in 2018 with the same parts even needing to be fixed. Talk about directly importing content. 

Fans have even had to make Quality of Life mods just to make the warehouse system somewhat useful. And then we have the driving. You can get an achievement for finishing the track in less than 1m50s. I assume they chose that relaxed time because cars become undriveable with any decent engine and no one would be able to get the achievement otherwise.

I really hoped this game would be a good step for series but I can tell they have done almost nothing in 3 years besides release a dumb number of licensed DLC. If I could give the company some advice, I'd say stop spending money on license deals with car brands and let fans mod the car names in themselves. Instead, work on the gameplay loop and make cars feel more unique. Stop giving us the exact same suspension/brake/transmission parts in every job. Work on driving and get creative with the perk system instead of dumb .05 sec examination bonuses. Here's hoping the next game can actually be unique and inspired instead of a copy paste.

I know nothing about cars. Nothing about how they are made, about the companies, about the history, about the models. Nothing. Yet somehow... this game is fun. Your brain isnt nearly as used in this game as you think, basically you take stuff out of the car, you order more, you put the new stuff in the car, you wash the car, you paint the car and then you put the finishing stuff on like a spoiler and bam you sell the car. Then you go to the barn/junkyard and pick up a new car to fix! Easy stuff. It can get complicated, but not enough to confuse you. The DLC may seem overwhelming, but im having fun without it for now. Maybe when i get a few more hours in ill buy all that dlc. Do yourself a favor and get this game. Remember: if you dont like it you can return it.

The game's interface is one of the worst I have ever seen.  I almost returned this game right away after seeing it.  In spite of that I have had a lot of fun playing this game, but not being able to return parts if you get the wrong one really ruins it for me.  Constantly I bump a button or miss read a part or don't realize its had extra letters and cant be used on the car I'm working on.  I is basically just wasted money.  I the real world if you get the wrong part you can just return it.  It happens all the time.  I have no idea why this was left out of the 3rd installment of this game but there is no excuse for this.  Also this game has a HUGE money issue.  You have to put all the money up to buy parts to repair cars.  There wouldn't be any car repair shops if there wasn't credit cards.  Companies cannot exist like that and to have a simulation game that you cannot put anyone on credits is terrible.   Either leave the money out or do it right.  Other than that this game is a lot of fun.  I looks great and is fun to play but really leaves a bad taste in my mouth with very easily fixable issues.  Again no excuse when its the 3rd game here.

I've been playing this game for some time now and I could say it's one of the games who remained with me since it has been released until now. It's really nice and interesting. It offers the possibility for any person do develop some knowledge on how an engine works and the main components of a car! (You won't became a mechanic for real but you will know how a spark plug looks and where a piston should be)

The graphics are really nice and the level of details on the machines, parts and garage are really good. The game play in the beginning is captivating but after some time, when you catch the move it kind of becomes boring. They have added a little bit of fun with the drag racing patch but it would be nicer if they could add some more new features. 

Maybe improve a bit the physics of the cars and add a drifting map. now a new map, only a track on the speed track. Or some more way of modifying parts, some events,  some new real cars (even if i see that they are adding some from time to time).

All in all is a really nice game and I can't wait to see what they will come with and see how things are evolving.

This game is very relaxing. You will find all sorts of cars from different eras, diagnose what is wrong with them, and get them back on the road again. It is a quintessential dad game, you get a list of things to fix, you fix them, and repeat. However it brings much more than that to the table, you will find yourself learning more about the different components of automobiles and what they do (albeit in a streamlined, gamified manner), which is compelling for both auto enthusiasts and amateurs alike.

I've really only played in sandbox mode so far, because I'm a car fanatic and I enjoy having access to everything all at once, but so far my experience has been nothing but positive (besides losing my save a couple times due to computer issues). I love being able to go out, find a junk car or maybe even just one that needs a little work, from the auctions or barns or junkyard, and being able to take it and turn it into something brand new and shiny. Plus, all the great workshop configs and mod cars keep it interesting and you never know what you'll find. The DLCs also add a lot of new vehicles and fun parts to play with, too.

In short, from what I've played of it, it's a fabulous game and it's a fun little time waster if you need somethin' to do for a while, just go right in and get a couple cars in sandbox and build 'em your way. Or if you're more into the progression and building yourself up type of thing (as i usually am), story mode is a great mode for you. Really, there's something for everyone here.

I can stress how much I love this game. I loved 2018 on the Xbox. I pretty much bought a pc for CMS 2021. This game improves on everything I felt 2018 was missing. IMO its one of the best simulators out there. It’s a very hard game to walk away from. Some tasks at times can be tedious (suspension replacement). Building engines and restoring cars is so much fun. I can’t wait to see how this game evolves over the years.
My suggestions/ideas for updates or the next game:

-I would like welding, repairing, washing and painting to be more user involved. This could add hours of gameplay. Grinding and welding frame/body parts would be so much more fun then just clicking one button. Prepping and priming a car for painting could be an entire process as well.

-Some kind of user manual for vehicles, nothing too in depth. Just something I can look through for model and trim types. I don’t like that have to click out of the game to see different trim options for a vehicle or what they are.

-A more in-depth photo mode, I take pictures of all my favorite builds. I would like to see an option where you can arrange a few vehicles and pose them.

-More options for parking your vehicles around your shop. I hate that I can’t see more of my favorite cars at a time.

- Every car in the game to be findable at the junk yard. Even if its crazy low odds (for instance .01% for a Lamborghini), but I think that would add nice little surprises and unanticipated excitement in the game when you go there. I just don’t like buying cars at auction, they are too clean. Every other junk pile has totaled Earthquake parts, but you can’t find the truck in the junk yard. The salon is just pointless IMO for this game at its current state.

-Old SUVs
Yes but it still needs improvements and additions to some parts. Otherwise its a nice time killer
