I think this is a great game. I started with the 2018 version and when I started,I had hardly any idea to what the inner workings of an engine were. I hardly knew the name of any part of a car. This has been a very informative game, teaching me the basics of an engine and suspension. While I think this is already a great game, it has a lot of room for improvement. There are no coolant hoses, brake lines, fuel lines, any AC components, the only interior components are the steering wheel and the seats, you cant test drive the cars on the road as many mechanics do to troubleshoot problems, there is no hard-to-reach bolts, and hardly any electrical components.

In a later version I would love to see, possibly in the expert difficulty as a lot of this may be considered more advanced:
-Hoses, electric cables, and lines for the hydraulic systems
-Requirement to torque bolts in certain patterns when needed, maybe add broken bolts or leaks when done improperly
-make the tight-to-reach spaces, as a lot of cars have the awkward placing of certain bolts behind frames and right up against another component
-add additional tools, different sized sockets that need to be switched out when a bolt is a different size
-add more interior components, interior fuse boxes, allow interacting with the cabin air filter and the radio
-add the ability to change light bulbs in the headlights and taillights
-add gaskets and leaks, and add transmission fluid for more maintenance
Since we don't buy cars that need more time in the shop than on the road, I never really have the opportunity to get to work on cars, so I just want a game that gets as close to the real deal as possible. The stuff above would be really cool, but even without it, this is a great game and I highly recommend it if you have an interest in cars, especially if you were like me and knew nothing about them, but wanted to learn. It gives you the basic knowledge of how an engine is assembled.

Jumping from 2015 to this was interesting.

There's certain parts of this that are strictly better: progression, the shop itself, the variety of vehicles, the varying locations. All of this is good. There's some new complexities in car tires which are functional, if rough, but much more clearly reflect actual reality.

Unfortunately some of these new systems really lack polish. Tires and rims added to the shopping list record their measurements from the car, but when you go to the actual purchase pages they don't auto-fill with these details and there's no way to access the shopping list to see this data. It's annoying having to find a place to jot down notes outside of the game for situations like this.

The official manufacturer DLC is also really odd in context. None of it is consistent with the fake lookalikes from the base game and their imaginary engines. For instance, despite a Nissan R34 lookalike with a fake RB engine being in the base game, the extremely common IRL RB engine swap isn't available for the Nissan S30 from the DLC. The same is also true of the lookalike Toyota Supra, whose IRL 1JZ & 2JZ engines are also popular swap options in many IRL vehicles. None of that real car culture carries over here. The same is also true of rotaries, from the Mazda DLC, which are also unavailable for swaps despite physically fitting into every vehicle in the game. The rotary engines are also arbitrarily missing common performance upgrades shared among other DLC vehicles, making these some of the slowest upgraded and tuned engines in the game. Notably, this is the opposite of how they perform and are utilized in real life.

The game also carries over some oddities from 2015 that it should have left behind. Chief among these are the original 2015 fake engines, which have not been significantly upgraded to improve their realism. Some of these look exceptionally out of place next to the actual masterpieces present in the Pagani and Porsche DLCs. The game also fails to understand the concept of a stud, mechanically, still only using the bolt attachment system from the base game. DLC engines which use studs have them oddly integrated, pre-built, into their individual components. Centerlock wheels from the DLCs are also completely misunderstood by the game, which treats them like standard multiple lug wheels with center hub caps. None of this is game breaking, but these are bad details to get wrong in a game about being a professional car mechanic.

The oddest design decisions come from the performance upgrades in the game. Supercharges and Turbocharges can't just be added to any vehicle or engine like they can IRL. They exist in the game, but only for completely separate engines that have to be entirely swapped to accommodate the performance bolt-on. These components also don't provide performance boosts by increasing effective engine displacement like in real life. Instead, they simply offer flat percentage-based increases of performance along with all the other "performance" components you can add to the vehicle. This leads to some very interesting situations that are the inverse of reality. Engines with more components like v12s get many more flat boosts than engines with single turbos. This causes huge engines to exceed 1000 HP without tuning and small turbo engines to struggle to improve performance versus their turbo-less counterparts. This is unintentionally hilarious for how poorly it reflects reality.

There's also some odd choices of what's available and not available for performance upgrades. If you asked most people with IRL performance mods what they did first to their car, aftermarket coil-overs would likely be high on the list. However, they aren't an option in this game. Meanwhile, performance power-steering pumps are readily available in the game's online shop for seemingly every car. I have no idea what a performance power steering pump even is, nor why it would positively influence horsepower. There's a lot of odd choices like this in the game. All clutches are single disc. Springs, retainers, and valves are all built into their heads. Wiring looms are completely omitted on new engines, but always partially included on engines with old-school distributors. In these cases, performance wire options which somehow influence horsepower are always available. Some turbo engines lack inter-coolers and some inter-cooler cars lack turbos. Kits to adapt carbureted engines to fuel injection and vice versa don't exist. Conversion of drum brakes to disc brakes are, likewise, not options even when parts to achieve this already exist in game. All cars also lack parking brakes, as either pads or shoes, and performance break pads are not an option even though performance rotors are. All of this makes the game come across as deeply silly at best, and oddly frustrating at its worst.

However, the oddest thing about the game is that it allows you to purchase, restore, upgrade, and tune vehicles with practically nothing to show for it. Fixed vehicles increase in value to net a profit, but tuning and painting vehicles do not further increase that profit. This would be fine if tuning and painting were their own rewards, but these mechanics are not particularly deep and there's not much to really do with the cars once you've gone through this. you can store the cars in an "alley" (effectively a storage unit), but you can't walk around the vehicles and experience them there. The game lacks online components for showing off builds to friends, and there's nothing equivalent to a car meet to showcase your skills and increase your visibility / business within the in-game car community. There is a drag strip and a race track, neither of which is directly indicated to the player, but the game's driving model is incredibly arcade-like for being a simulator. The two feel like very different kinds of experiences and I don't personally understand the cross-over enough to jump from one to the other. I'm here for casual car LEGOs, not high-octane racing action, and the game doesn't even attempt to hold your hand and guide you between one and the other. It's almost like it just threw all this at the wall in the hopes that something would stick. Maybe spending more time with the game will change my mind, but I can't say it currently makes a lot of sense as is.

Barn Finds, The Junkyard, and The Auction Houses are all fine mechanically but I wish they would learn some things from each other. Being able to walk around the auction lot, like you can in the other two settings, would be nice. Having variety to junkyard layouts, like the Barn Finds have, would also be great. It's weird how certain car parts are repairable and other ones arbitrarily aren't, but the mini-games that exist for dealing with these parts work well and are mechanically enjoyable, even if the premise behind them isn't rooted in reality. Speaking of reality, don't expect realistically simulated engine failures. Every part is rated on a 0 to 100% scale of how rusty it isn't, which is hilarious.

All of this is to say the game is good fun. It's silly, it misinterprets some things, and it's going to make some very technical people very frustrated, but it's mostly just good fun. There's no other game where you can place a 24/7 auto-repair shop on the side of Route 66 and have random people bring in their rusty Paganis for simple oil changes. It's a ridiculous and amazing rags to riches story starring you. It moves at your own pace, starting from a mechanic that can barely afford to change someone's oil and ending when you fill up your 5th mini-store-it with your private collection of rare Hyper-Cars and personally decide to call it quits. Make no mistake, there's nothing else quite like this. It's a unique game that does some lovely things, and it's a real breath of fresh air compared to a lot of what's out there. I hope the developers make some changes here, but what's present is still a fun time. Recommended.

After playing for over 50 Hours of in game time i have finally decide to give this a Final Review. Overall the game is amazing with new features such as adding fluids, using decrease for the bolts and much more. Added mini games for like balancing out the tire and what not. Being able to go outside of the garage is a major plus as well consider in 18 u where unable to do that. The game is by far a 10 out of 10 for me and the graphics are excellent. The reason this would have been amazing is because alot of the cars that you buy at the junkyard usually end up with alot of rust. That rust will not come off on it own there for there are certain things u may need to get the rust off of the car. That stuff would have been handy. The rust does come off on certain body parts that you can easily take off and replace with new parts but the main thing is the main body of the car. Once u take all of the parts off and u replace it with new parts u will sometimes still see rust on the main body of the car itself. That what would be nice to be able to take off. If you're as much of a car fan as I am than just know, as much as I love this experience its a sub-par mechanic simulator that teaches you the basics of the cars you get to work on. And I REALLY mean basics. You're never going to have to deal with real life car problems, just basic function like if the engine is in good condition or if it's even there. Because of that a bit of immersion is lost from the get-go as you're not being asked to completely rewire a car just to get it running, which is something I can't complain about much. "Condition" just means how rusty the part is, you could have a car built with 5% quality parts and it'll run just as well as something you spent 30,000 CR on refurbishing. Car controls aren't that good but i'm not going to judge the game on just that. If you're here to build some cars and not be able to drive them well (besides forking over half the price of the game for a drag strip mode lmao), I'd recommend this. 7/10

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is a simulation game that allows players to take on the role of a car mechanic and repair, paint, and customize a wide variety of vehicles. The game features a realistic and detailed garage environment, as well as a wide variety of tools and equipment to use for repairs. The graphics are detailed and create a believable and immersive garage environment. The sound design is also well done, adding to the overall atmosphere of the game.

One of the strengths of Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is the game's attention to detail and realism. The game features a wide variety of vehicles and parts, as well as a realistic and detailed garage environment, which makes it stand out among other car mechanic simulation games. The game also has a wide variety of tools and equipment to use for repairs, which adds to the realism and immersion.

Another strength of the game is the ability to customize vehicles, players can paint and upgrade their vehicles, as well as add custom parts, allowing players to express their creativity. The game also includes a realistic damage system, where players must diagnose and repair the damage, adding to the game's replayability.

Overall, Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is a detailed and realistic car mechanic simulation game that offers a unique and exciting experience for players. The game's attention to detail, wide variety of vehicles and parts, and customizable options make it stand out among other car mechanic simulation games. It's a game that is perfect for those who have an interest in cars, mechanics, and want a realistic simulation experience.

Great relaxing game, they improved on every key feature from the previous edition, they need to fix the story missions, most of them are ridiculous, "i use this car eveyday, it could use a tune up" the car doesn't even start if you don't pull the entire engine apart.
It could really use Vulkan implementation plus FidelityFX, for some reason they refuse to implement it.
Most DLCs have too few cars, mostly less than 5, and even down to 2 cars, which is a missed opportunity.
I wish we could color match car parts to the car, but for some reason they don't believe in different materials painting the same color, which is very frustrating and ruins customization.
Some engines desperately need a revamp, they got carried over from previous versions of the game and look very bad in this version (such as the modern V8 not having camshaft caps, or the timing belts connection to a teethless shaft).
Price is good, both the base game and the DLCs, but is hard to understand why the developer is so stubborn on some very much requested features.
With the release of the Drag Racing DLC the game has improved a lot, but when the game is now centered around racing, having cars with missing performance parts it's a shame, and it shouldn't be so hard, just make a list of all standard parts that can have a performance counterpart and then add them, it's not like is hard, most of the times is the same parts but chrome.

Overall recommended, wish they listen more to the customers.

I absolutely recommend this game.
It is getting better every time they release a new one and I'm sure it's only gonna keep on getting better.
There are only two major things I would add to the game that would make it infinitely times better.
First of those two things would be multiplayer. It would make it, in my opinion, from a great game to one of the best games out there. The thought alone of being able to play this with my brother is damn near breathtaking and I am genuinely sad that I can not.
The other thing that this game needs, again, in my opinion, is a much, much, much harder difficulty. Playing the game on any difficulty that is currently available is too easy, and gets too repetitive if you do it too much too fast. I am sure that in about 3 hours of play time I would be able to afford to buy a car, and after fixing it in about 30 minutes that I would be able to just start repeating that process, and 'beat' the game on that save file. So I highly recommend a difficulty that is much more like real life, because I doubt I would be able to afford a car in 3 hours in real life, starting from nothing.

TL:DR
Much needed multiplayer and much needed harder difficulty with a more real life economy.

The good: Graphics are decent, and it runs well if that sort of things matters to you. There are lots of cars, and the repair/rebuild systems are fairly deep. Anyone can see my playtime, and it took me about that long to 100% achievement the game on normal, though you could surely do it faster. There are lots of "story" missions, lots of cars one can try to collect, a skill tree - though its more of a brick than a tree - and actual driving mechanics. Overall, worth the $25.

The "meh": A lot of the above could be cooler/more fun/more enjoyable than they are. There's plenty to do, but about 100 hours in you're doing much the same thing over and over. The Barn/Auctions/Junkyards are wonky sources of underpriced cars. Most of the cars have the same underlying "builds" even if they are completely different models or styles of car. For example, there is only one transmission set up that connects to multiple different gearboxes. The story missions don't have much story to them outside a page of text. The repair shop itself has a lot of character, but not much is done with it. 

The bad: Motion blur. The driving mechanics. If you expect to put any car together with the best parts and no more thought than that, you're gonna immediately roll it on the test track. Or maybe you're better at it than me. 

Overall, a decent game. I hope there's a 2023, or a 2024. My biggest hope is that they improve on the redundant parts of the game. Have fun.

I'd still like to see more off-road vehicles like the Jeeps, Toyotas, and now the Bronco, along with an off-road track with some realistic physics. I understand that isn't the point of the game, but it certainly could add a new level of fun for those of us who'd like to combine the building of CMS21 with the driving of Snow/Mudrunner.

I absolutely love this game!! I would  love to see more DLC cars and and more variety in vehicles (having boxer engines) that would be amazing! Also bring more of the trucks back please. 

The whole game play is way better than 2018 CMS by far! The game has so much potential like add more stuff to the car like hoses cables adding fuel like let's put that gas station to work!!  Also let us drive to junkyard, auctions, barn finds or just a small free roam map in general would be awesome!!

The car handling needs a little work in some places but overall not bad considering the game is a "car mechanic sim" not driving sim. 

The customer jobs are a fun way to burn an hour or so. For new players they can be challenging but progressively get more challenging, teaching you how to do stuff as you go. I love the garage customisation and progression as you unlock skill points to equip your shop with more tools like the restoration tools and welder.

If the game is missing anything, I'd say being able to display cars is one of them. You only get five spaces at the workshop for parking which is taken up by orders and barn finds, otherwise it's off site storage. Also when you spend tons of scrap making an awesome 3 Star car it kinda sucks as nobody will ever see it... I think multiplayer would be a fun addition as kicking back, working together on a car with some mates could be enjoyable.

Overall the game as a whole is excellent and I would recommend it to anyone who wants to learn about cars and how they work. Getting money in this game is not extremely difficult and creating your own builds (engine swapping) is fun. Also the dyno and paint booth open possibilities for veterans keeping the game fresh.

Its a really cool game. What made me get this was a free app on android called Retro Garage, has similar (albeit much less feature full) game play and it made me really want to buy this game for the full experience. I 100% recommend if you have any mechanical sense and like fixing car engines and suspension systems. The "normal" way of playing; taking orders and fixing customers issues is probably the worst way to make money, unless you choose the jobs with the most expensive parts. It's best to grind a bit til you get $20-30k, buy yourself a junkyard car(a cheap one, less than 5k) then restore it. I myself grinded for a while, made some mistakes and left my save for dead. So I started a new one with the name "cms2021stage2" and that spawns you at level 12, a nice chunk of change, and plenty of skill points so I didnt feel like my time was wasted when I made some simple mistakes and lost all of my money on my 9 hr save.

Absolutely fun game - I mean 100 hours and counting speak for itself. They clearly strived for a more simplified, fast-paced experience. So, if you are looking for a hyper-realistic simulator: this is not it.
Instead, you will be able to rebuild an entire engine within minutes. But there is still a great sense of achievement and satisfaction when you are looking at a shiny new car, where an hour ago was just a pile of rusty parts. Ah and yeah obviously car go vroom.
I'm still wondering how they are not getting sued for copying cars with minor differences and then just calling them e.g. FMWs.
If you want officially licensed content, you have to pay extra for DLCs. But DLC parts are also a step up in realism / quality. And new, unique parts obviously break the monotony.

Some good improvements over 2018.. the driving of the cars has gotten better, still some room for improvement but definitely good enough now to have some fun driving your builds now. The new Garage is really cool, love the way you can expand it out into new buildings, gives it a much cooler feel over 2018. The only thing you could knock it on is that you can only have 2 car hoists where as 2018 you could have 3 hoists. 9 hours in I can feel I will be getting my moneys worth with this game.. many more hours play left in it.

Still a couple of things I would like to see implemented... 

I would like to be able to drive my cars around my garage, Who does not want to leave a big skid in their driveway after building a supercharged monster.

I would like to be able to cruise the streets in my cars, drive to the POI's instead of just clicking map and clicking Auction then teleporting there.. would be much cooler to jump in ya Hot Rod and drive to the Junkyard or where ever.. or just go for a cruise.

Regardless, great game!

First was Car Mechanic Simulator 2018. An excellent sim game, but there was quite a bit missing in terms of mechanic abilities and depth of parts & such. Not only did it fix everything wrong from the 2018 version (which, as I mentioned; was a great game overall), but they managed to bring us all new features and abilities! This game is an excellent evolution in the franchise and the new licences and content are expanding the game so that it will probably be difficult for them to make a new iteration unless they manage to include the licenced content from this game in the next game from day one. 

Pro's - More cars om the basic game, the introduction of EV's to the franchise in the Electric Car DLC, the introduction of fluids to be changed other than just oil, the introduction of fuses, relays and ECU's, Got rid of the RNG repair game and replaced it with a mini game that means a 92% quality part won't be completely destroyed if you fail to repair it, the introduction of a car washing and detailing bay, better junkyard experience, more parts can be now be painted,  the range of performance parts has been expanded to more than just engine parts and gearboxes, etc...

Cons - Only 2 lifters in the garage instead of the 3 from the last game, car parking for owned cars is now just a row of garage doors instead of a multi-storey car parking facility and you cannot freely walk up and down the row of cars you own,

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing. fr tho this is so good

So, I took a while to write this review as i thought i would try and get a good bit through the game before giving my final thoughts on it. It's been a really tough time trying to work out if i would recommend this game to someone or not and after a long time of thinking about it, i have to say i wouldn't. 

The game is just too much like 2018, There is really no major differences to warrant spending the full price on this game when you can just get basically the exact same game (with better DLC *Currently*) in the 2018 version. I love this game, don't get me wrong, as someone who loves cars, this is a great time waster/chill game to just chip away the time at, however, the actual *story* missions in the game get very repetitive (as they would when you can only sort, engine/drive-train/suspension/bodywork, there's only so many variants you can do i suppose!)

The biggest issue i have with the game is the totally pointless spreading out of all the points of the garage! i was so hyped to see we finally get paint-able mechanical parts! to then find out that instead of having my spray booth in my garage like 2018 (nice and convenient!!) i now have to leave the garage, go over the small road then through into the spray booth. the same is for the test path, car wash and dyno! the biggest pain in the hole though, is why does my garage not even have a work bench to begin with?? i have to pay to have a work bench in my garage AFTER i save up to get an extension to my garage first?? why can i have a bloody massive school bus in my garage but not a work bench?? and even when i do finally get a work bench, i have to leave my garage to go into a separate part of my garage to repair items! WHY WOULD I NOT HAVE A WORK BENCH NEAR MY RAMPS?!?! select to take your car into the garage onto the ramps and for some reason it puts you at the side of the ramp without the controls? this seems completely useless to me and just really annoying more than a big game issue.

Auctions!! 
These once again, although better set out, are still mostly the AI ensuring you will rarely get a good deal on a car. start an auction as many times as you like and don't bid and the price will normally be lucky to clear 50% of it's estimated value. start a bid and actually bid through for any car and i bet 8/10 times the bots will drive you up to market value and generally higher. super annoying again! Bidder 1 Coming in Outta No Where! 

PARTS UPGRAGES!!
This is by far the biggest con and the most annoying part of the game as i have found out playing more! you need scrap to upgrade parts via the upgrade bench, outside in a container, obviously! However what is massively annoying is the time it takes to actually fully upgrade everything and the sheer effort that needs to go into doing so!! i decided (for some stupid reason) to fully upgrade every part on my fully modified turbo'd Supa, and compare against an identical non upgraded fully modified turbo Supa to see if there was any real point to doing so. i started off with 7,500+ scrap, which i thought would have been more than enough to get me through the build, however it was no where near enough to get through the build! i hardly allowed me to upgrade the entire rear end! i then needed to keep trying to pick up parts, then trying to convert it to actual scrap, which is where the biggest issue lies! the value for scrap is so far out of wack it literally makes no sense and is totally unfair on the player. For instance, a piston ring or even a rod cap will on max scrap, allow you 3 scrap, but guess what? a massive front subframe or even some body panels, only offer 3 scrap!! how the hell can i get 3 scrap from tiny pieces yet massive ones i get the same amount?!!?! yeah you occasionally get engine blocks that offer 26 etc but again this is only if you land on 1 block out of the however many there is to land on and is totally not right in my opinion and drags out and totally makes it worthless to upgrade car parts as the time put into actually getting the items upgraded is not nearly worth the out come. 
UPGRADE TURBO SUPA HP GAIN 169+/-
NON-UPGRADED TURBO SUPA HP GAIN 145+/-
Not worth the time in my eyes and needs fixing!

so basically, i don't really rate the game more than 2018, i honestly feel they would have been better making a big update DLC for 2018 rather than making this a full game on it's own. maybe with more time and a lot of fine polishing, this might become the proper game it deserves to be!

Positives;
Paint-able Mechanical Parts
Better Repair System 
Better Race Track/Top Speed Track
Finally Added Upgraded Brake Discs! 
Better Paint options and a couple more modified parts.
Window Tinting! 
Tune Friendly ECUs!
Drag Racing!

Negatives; 
Stupid Spaced Out Buildings!!
No Real Increase in New Vehicles 
Story Mode Pretty Repetitive
Auctions Still all Over The Place
THE LOUDEST INTRO TO A GAME IN HISTORY!!!
Scrap/Upgrade System
Stupid ECU Upgrade Programme.

Having played two of the previous games in this series, the 2021 version is no doubt the best one you can play. It is a complete upgrade with enhanced gameplay compared to its older selves. In addition to more options while in the shop, you've now got a property where multiple buildings and other "garages" can be made out into a paint shop, junk space, car wash, and more. There are more options for the test track and race track. The junkyard, barns, and dealerships all offer new and different ways to obtain more cars and parts.

The vanilla game you buy is excellent, but I must say, getting some of the paid DLC + community DLC makes this game shine a lot brighter. Across the board, every new car model you add to the game breathes extra life into nearly every facet of the game. Not only does it add new cars, but new parts, liveries, customizable options for other cars, a better variety mix when salvaging, junking, barn hunting, and more. If you buy this game, I implore you to at least check out the free DLC the modding community has to offer as a lot of it is pretty rad.

All-in-all, the ~66 hours I put into this game were great and I absolutely recommend it. I'm not really a car enthusiast and I know nothing about car work or mechanics. So, it's still a wonder how I came to like this series so much but it largely is due to the excellent work Red Dot Games has put into it.

TLDR: Its just CMS 2018 but shinier and more mini games. They didn't really improve any of the main mechanics. Copy paste, don't waste your money.

---------------------------

To be more specific; I love the CMS series. But its kinda gotten stale. The same mechanics, not really a lot of new stuff, and I bet its just going to be another DLC queen. Its just starting to seem like a cash grab instead of a game. There could've been wayyyy cooler mechanics for the minigames instead of just "Ooo will you click green or red who knows". I really wish there was some kind of physical tool you could use to repair body panels and paint things your own way. It would be cool if you could cut out your own stencils to make your own liveries on cars. This game could've gone so many different ways than it did.

What I would have liked to have seen:

- As mentioned above, more in depth painting ability. Right now its pretty lack luster.

- The repair system and "upgrade" system make very little sense. There could've been so much more here if you just looked, tools to repair certain parts where you use the mouse to shave off rust and knock out dents with hammers. The tech tree could've accompanied this with those specific tools instead of just "Hee hoo here's a repair table"

- The fact that you can chop shop cars with no repercussions is startling. The customer never ever comes back to check on their car? They just trust you'll take care of it forever? Come on now. The customers themselves could use work. They could be actual physical people who drop off their cars to you. Drive up and just leave it for ya to repair. You could've had "Day/Night" cycles where customer cars have a certain period you have to get them done by before the customer starts getting angry. Customers should also notice if you've changed their tires to be the absolute cheapest you could find. Its ridiculous the amount of things you can get away with.

The cars themselves seem just repeated every single game. There's a couple of new ones which is nice, but the engines are mostly the same, the mechanics for repairing the engines is mostly the same, and everything is just kinda bleh now. There's nothing NEW or EXCITING about CMS anymore.

ECU Tuning is matching bars together. Don't get to actually adjust the ECU. Same thing with carburetors. Can't change the timing, can't change the cam lobe size, can't adjust your lifters, can't adjust your suspension, can't adjust your camber/tow, can't adjust ANYTHING. Testing tools are useless (again). Easier to just take apart the car and find the part that's broke (Have to do it anyways so might as well). This isn't Car Mechanic Simulator this is clicking simulator with cars and engines included.

This Developer consistently reuses their assets to create "new" games. All of these games have the same mechanics in one way or another and are throw together with chewing gum and pop-sickle sticks. This was a barely rebranded Car mechanic sim 2018. If you loved 2018 just stick with that because this adds nothing that will make the experience better.

Avoid this dev and their sister companies if you prefer games with a good content to value ratio

Overall it's an entertaining game that flexes and shows the potential power of the simulation genre.
However, what it lacks are some key things to keep the majority engaged beyond the honey moon phase of the simulation experience. Here are some of the things that can be done to elevate the experience.
1. I know this is not an easy fix by any means but it would be nice to have car specific parts rendered in. You will see time after time that cars (no matter the manufacturer or model) share the the same brake system, suspension, coolant, power steering, filters, and many many more identical components. This takes you completely out of being immersed and starts to get mundane after time. The great thing about being in mechanics is feeling like you have mastered a specific manufacturer or model due to your experience with it. This game doesn't make you feel that passion. I would start by at least creating unique parts by for each manufacturer so that high end cars get that feeling of being exotic.
2. Day to day cycling should be a thing here. The leveling progression should be complemented with an in game time clock or calendar cycle. To fix this when you accept a job you should be assigned a number of days to complete the job. Then you should need to review the vehicle and order parts, parts should not be instantly provided from shopping, the parts should come the  next day and some parts 2 to 3 days (unless you pay for rush shipping). The player should have to 'end the day' to proceed, kinda like life. Adding this challenge for the player of timing the part arrivals to meet the deadlines is huge. When your parts come in and you can finish the job it releases more space in your shop for the next job. I would also add a time clock slider and allow players to select their shift hours. The slider can control the ratio of "in game" time passage vs real time to scale a day/night cycle. You can then see how many 'hours' it took you in game to perform the repair, leverage that against the job earnings to make this feel more like a real shop. The better you get, the less time it takes you to do the tasks, the more tasks you can do per shift, the more profit you turn and the feeling of accomplishment will grow.  This adds more authenticity to the experience, makes the player feel rewarded and skilled, and negates the current feeling I get when playing "that I'm fixing 1000 cars a day" which isn't realistic by any means.  Also, have several procedural jobs the player can review so they can pick 2 or 3 at the start (progression to 5 or 6 dependent on shop slots that open as you upgrade) that they want to perform for that 'calendar day' and the flow of the game will feel much better. As they upgrade the shop the ability to perform more jobs would carry over providing the feeling of growth with purpose. If they select to many jobs and can't complete them in the day/night cycle time to meet the job deadlines, then they get bad customer reviews which impacts XP or restricts certain jobs until the player reaches 5 star rating level. To me this is the element that would push me most to desire playing the game. By challenging myself to reach higher shop production, profit and quality per day cycle.
3.  A minor improvement requested. Steering with keyboard control is terrible. There should be an option for controller support or a selection to change to mouse steering. I never understood why mouse steering isn't a thing, allow me to change to head movement with the mouse when holding right click and when i let go of the right click control the wheel again. Just in case i want to look around. If there is a way to fix this, please let me know. But right now testing or track running cars just isn't as enjoyable as it should be.

Anyway..these are a few big things that I wish the developers would considered changing. 

As i support simulation titles as a whole, and genuinely believe the future of our education system and OJT programs will rely heavily on virtual simulations for career development, I'm recommending this title in support of this developer and those like them.

I'm not really sure what it is about this game that keeps dragging me back. The controls and camera movement issues can be really janky at times (you put your camera in a certain position then it resets to some random spot after removing or adding a part, etc), but there is something so addictive about being able to fully pull apart a car and put it back together. I really enjoyed playing this game, but it definitely won't be for everyone. The story line (if you could call it that) is more of a tutorial than anything else. And once that's done? Well, you'll get pretty bored, pretty quickly, especially if you get all the achievements. If you don't purchase any DLC (there are many) then you'll be disenchanted pretty quickly. But on the upside, this game will really teach you about the different parts of a car, just don't expect to be a fully qualified mechanic or anything after.

Suggestions that are necessary or I won't play again:

1. Have a "Mark All" button for car parts that need replacing, to mark all parts at once rather than going thru each page, one item at a time....

2. Un-Mark the parts after they've been properly replaced.

3. Add the mark feature to body parts? Thought this was obvious...

4. Auto save WAY MORE OFTEN..... I bought a car at auction, replaced absolutely everything except the tires and the game crashed and I reverted all the way to before I bought the car at auction....  lost 1+ hours of progress.

5. For $300 you should be able to call in help to find a part that you may be struggling on.

6. Make the Engine Lift more intuitive and obvious. Took me forever to realize I could add it to the other engine lift in the repair room.

7. There should be a way to estimate the amount one will need to complete a repair (replacement parts etc) and how much of a reward it will give.

Within the confines of the Yes/No system, I feel that this game definitely is worth playing if you enjoy simulators or just enjoy working on cars. You inherit or purchase an older garage and start off taking vehicle maintenance and repair jobs.  You can perform some troubleshooting, vehicle inspection, and part replacement at first, then work your way up to a full-service vehicle restoration shop: Part and panel repair, car wash, detailing, window tinting, painting, wheel and headlight alignment, and dyno testing. You can purchase wrecks from the junkyard to rebuild, hit auctions to buy cars in various conditions, find old and forgotten vehicles in barns, or purchase them brand new if you so choose.  This game does the treatment of vehicle components and assembly well and the leveling system that lets you improve your abilities, add to your garage, and improve overall game play efficiency doesn't feel taxing -- but can be gamed if you pay attention. The spray booth can create some interesting paint colors and appearances and many of the cars come with liveries to add racing stripes, racing regalia, or even business logos.  

As a "backyard mechanic" I've found that I have one sticking complaint: I feel that some of the requirements are a bit too strict in regards to removal and installation of parts. For example, removing the wheel hub assembly, including potentially the attached braking components, is something that can be done IRL but not in this sim, and steering hub housings are required to be placed (read: Left dangling with nothing holding it in-place) before attaching the appropriate control arms. While this is a minor gripe, it can be a little immersion breaking.  Additionally, while the music included with the game isn't bad in any sense, the playlists are rather short and become repetitive. While you have the ability to add your own music and create your own playlists, this relies on having the music files stored on your PC or accessible via a cloud connection, meaning if you're using a music streaming service you will be turning it off instead of using the in-game radios for control.

Overall, I do like this game, as my 404 hours of game play can attest.  My minor gripes are just that: Minor.

The pros:
This is quickly becoming one of my favorite games, I've put 25 hours into it so far and I've had it less than 3 days. It's not too difficult to level up but it is not easy either. You will have to grind a bit to make money and unlock tiers and also gain skill points. I did not purchase anything major till today, I got the first level garage expansion and paint shop but I waited till I had enough funds stacked and not be left penniless. You can't fix cars if you can't buy the parts. So yea, you have to be thinking ahead always. I like that part, being strategic is very important to growing and it is a business so you want to be successful. There are more pros but I'm not going to mention each one. The graphics are really good and the game runs quite well with no lag or nasty stutters. Your experience may not be the same as mine but it's not a really resource intensive game. I run on the max settings and have no problems whatsoever.
The CMS 2021 has a lot to offer in their workshop. Take a look around and see some really good creations.
The price is fair and I'd buy this game any day for the regular cost. If it were a few bucks more I'd say wait till it's on sale.
Now the Cons:
Quirky ways of moving around under the car or in the engine area, it should be simple to go from removal and installing of parts. It's not always so, I end up with my face inside of tires or motors just because it's how this game works. You can click through to each spot you want to move to next but it can get quite frustrating sometimes. I decided to just use ESC and move to the next location I want to get to on the vehicle. It's better than clicking around every car part till it gets you close to where you want to be. Honestly it is also less disorienting and I don't end up inside a car wheel.
Another con is that the pay is quite low starting out for most jobs. It should be adjusted so you're not getting an unrealistic amount for the work involved. Maybe the dev studio is not quite attuned to how much it really costs to have this work done. They don't take into account the cost of materials and labor. It just does not add up at all and I have noticed that sometimes you may barely make enough to cover the parts alone and you're getting basically nothing for your labor. That is a huge fail to me and it needs to be addressed. I'd really like to see that changed because it will cause you to struggle and you get hardly anything when selling off the old parts. Yet you have to sell the old parts to make something because scrapping them is only useful when you can afford to expand and buy work benches. The grind and struggle are real when you start out, but it should be more balanced.
This is the gist of my review of what I really like and things that could be better, the details hopefully convey the reasons why I hit on certain points mentioned. It's just my own opinion, I do like the game and I definitely will keep playing CMS 2021.

PSA FOR ALL INTEL GRAPHICS USERS

For anyone who has Intel Graphics and takes the chance of "GAME DOES NOT SUPPORT Intel Integrated Graphics Cards" and still purchases... I am here to tell you... it is true.  (Currently running: Intel Iris XE and MAX Graphics.)

If you go and apply all the Lowest Quality Settings, it is like a PowerPoint slide show and not smooth, but it is tolerable (29 hours played on Intel Graphics) if you don't crave high performance on every game you play.
If you have all the Highest Quality Settings, you have now gone to Warp speed and you can no longer do anything without major motion blur and massive frame rate drops... now it's unplayable. 

Just putting my two cents in for someone considering overlooking the graphics requirements.

This is a very fun game though, highly recommended for a weekend lazy day of casual gaming!

Great game, only could use an autosave feature. Have had it freeze completely on me 3 times, losing 1 to 1,5 hours worth of playtime each freeze.

Edit: We REALLY NEED a more regular Autosave, game's been freezing on me a lot lately and making me lose 30 minutes to an hour of progress. Would be great if we can add a time interval in the settings. Won't be editing this review until we get this feature.

Fun simulator. Learning all about the mechanics of cars, yet a fun game to play. Not sure about the scrap set up as it takes so long to get enough scrap to convert a car. Love the game and learning new things. Hoping someone make a Saab edition.

pros:
You can learn a lot about where parts are located, how you can change them etc. Ofcourse in a very simplified way.
There's a wide variety of car models with unique to the brand parts placement.

flaws:
The tutorial is not really nonproductive for a very new player of the CMS games.
A lot of struggle with blue parts farm.
The drag/speed track is not very keyboard+mouse friendly. If you tune up your car you will have hard time keeping it straight.
The shopping is kind of annoying to use. Would've been great if items from shopping list disappeared after you buy the part.
The warehouse is absolutely useless at the stage it is.

So far, after more than 30 hours:  

1) Every single time I thought I'd found a "bug" -- it wasn't a bug.   I needed to look closer and have patience.

2) Every single time I felt like the user interface could be improved, like with camera movement or autopart purchase -- it turned out that I just needed a bit more thoughtful practice before I developed a routine and all started to seem smooth and easy to use.

Now I think this game is a gem.   A real ruby, or even a diamond.   

Now I'm jealous of car mechanics.

The interface is extremely counter-intuitive and frustrating at first.  I find that really gives you the feeling of frustration and anger associated with working on cars in real life.  But once you get used to it, it's usable, but never great.
Having said that, this game is beautiful.  I've been just buying up cars in barns and prettying them up and it's like a zen practice where I just slowly work from dust-covered junk on the lift to gleaming chrome on a dynamometer.  It's easy to lose track of time playing it.

This game is so fun, it's ASMR for car enthusiasts.  It's fun stripping down an entire car, and rebuilding it from the ground up.  If you are a real life mechanic, it's not super realistic, but realistic enough. 

Lots of cool cars, and you can bring them on the track, test drive them etc.  Community mods are nice as well. 

The game starts to really shine when you can customize the car, and start building what you want on your own.  Upgrading parts, tuning them etc.  This is a great game to play while having something in the background, it's pretty relaxing. 

I bought this the other day and already have 18 hrs in.  The game loop is really fun.  The game gave me a little bit of an appreciation on how painful it must have been to work on V8 carbed engines.

It's similar to the previous games but also has some improvements: stuck bolts, more liquid based tanks (windshield wash, powersteering etc). Also like to new drain tool. Recommend if you like some sandpit games! :)

I would recommend this CMS '21 to anyone who wants a simulator that lets you learn and play at the same time.  Now I wouldn't say this game is even close to 100% accurate to actual mechanics, as there are no gaskets, wiring and spark chasing, vacuum hoses to run (or find in some pain in the arse cases), tight spaces and torque requirements don't factor into the job and apparently you always know where the 10mm socket is (the most unrealistic part of the game).  The game will give you an entry level insight into part placement and function, and may peak your interest into certain components that may prompt you to research things you otherwise wouldn't know the question to ask.  After you have (or if you have) a thorough basic knowledge of mechanics you'll get to the point you can just shut your brain off and just relax as you take a rusted jalopy from the junkyard and turn it into a highly tuned masterpiece.

Holy Motion Sickness, Batman!!!
I love this game... but...
If you are at all sensitive, you will get horrible motion sickness.... even after just one minute.
You can mitigate some motion sickness by playing at the lowest graphics settings to get the highest frames per second possible, but even then, the game causing motion sickness will severely limit your ability to play for any length of time
Many first person games do not cause motion sickness, and we know what causes motion sickness in the 21st century... and it is not the gamers' monitors or PC's, so don't gaslight us. This is entirely the responsibility of the developer.
I will change my review when they fix the game.

I have enjoyed every minute of this game, from the introductory mission grind to being able to fully renovate a scrap to a 100% build.  By far my number one game played throughout 2022.  DLC expansions of remastered packs from the previous games in the franchise have been a blast with more still in the pipeline from Red Dot Games.  There is not enough praise on how CMS21 completely time sinks from painting all the individual parts, to part refurbishment, warehouse management and garage customisation.

Easy 10/10

☑ Detailed Engines from Inline-3 to V12's.
☑ Addictive once familiar with the mechanics.
☑ Fantastic mixed electro/dubstep soundtrack.
☑ Aesthetically pleasing bolt and part removal sounds.
☑ For newcomers: Hard to learn but easy to master.

Overall the game is very enjoyable.  The amount of effort to unlock the perks is pretty minimal.  It all happens naturally as you play the story.  Troubleshooting is fun.  Building cars from scratch is fun and rewarding to take out and test.  Picking cars is a surprising dopamine hit.  My biggest grips would be as you progress in the story almost all of the later ones are complete engine rebuilds.  While I dont mind rebuilding the engine occasionally,  having to take one completely apart to get a crank shaft for one story, then pistons and rings for another story just wears thing pretty quickly.  It feels like 7/10 story jobs Ive done have required the engine to be significantly disassembled.  

The 2nd issue I have is jobs have a minimum repair level a replaced part needs to be.  For examples sake lets say its 80%.  You only have to replace parts that are below 25%.  So the game requires you to specifically put the part above 80% in the bad parts spot.  You could have multiple similar parts of varying levels of wear, and they are fine and dont need to be replaced, but if you put one of them in the replacement part spot and it doesnt meet the replacement threshold its marked as incomplete.  Now this is fine on the car, where you can highlight the exact part that needs the replacement.  However when you take the engine out this feature does not work.  So your stuck memorizing exactly which parts need to be replaced with the new part or else youll be stuck rebuilding the engine all over again.   I eventually circumvented this by just buying all new parts for the engine when it was in question.  But that didnt really feel like a good resolution to my problem as a player.

Overall, good game I just feel like engine work could be a little better for player experience.

This game is pretty fun. It has some quirks but I think it's a matter of balancing the level of detail.

Good things:
* Getting to take apart and reassemble various cars is the main draw here.
* You get to see a lot of different components (and different types of components) and learn how they work with the rest of the components.
* "Story" cars have amusing backstories.
* Generally pretty easy going. Has enough handicaps to allow you to easily repair most cars (as long as you can find all the broken parts).
* A good variety of cars, from modern to 50+ year old models, and lots of variety in the types/origins - Japanese, American, German/European; muscle, sports, standard passenger cars. Although real-life names aren't used (except in DLC and Workshop content), it's often clear where the inspiration comes from.

Bad things
* Some stuff is simplified for sure. For example, there is no implementation of things like brake lines. If brakes aren't working, you can just replace the discs, calipers, pads, ABS Pump, and ABS unit (name?). No transmission fluids; just oil, washer fluid, brake fluid, power steering fluid.
* It seems like some of the translations/objectives are somewhat unclear. For example ,"paint with factory paint." Does that just mean ONLY the default factory paint assigned when you go to the paint shop? Also, if the driver doesn't want their company/dad to know the car had to be repaired, why would painting it a slightly different color be acceptable?
* Any parts that are damaged just show up as rusty, and if you inspect them, you learn their "condition" percentage. Personally I would like a little more variety in this, as in real life, a new part that was damaged in a recent accident wouldn't just be completely rusted out. Maybe show bent or cracked parts? Idk - I'm not a car repair expert.
* Why is it that some kinds of parts just can't be repaired? It makes sense for something like Brake pads. But muffler components?
* Adding a lot of Workshop content makes the "junkyard" and "barn" unusable. If you download a pack with 30 different varieties of Ford Mustang, every other car/part you find could be some version of a Mustang, when you might be trying to find components from a different particular car model. would like to have an "activate/deactivate content" menu.

Great game but I feel like they could add one more thing to really give it a legendary status. 

 I feel like all cars of same model are identical, if you buy auction or barn car, they are always very consistently damaged all over. It missing a "reason" why it was parked/owner don't want it. IMHO something like modifiers should be added to the game, that tell a bit greater story than 3 stars almost identical to the others. 

lets say car could have tiny backstories, that gives some parts better or worse condition. Stuff like:

"hail damage" (very  damaged body, but internally ok), "cracked block", "wrong fluids", "pothole" (one wheel missing or very damaged, with suspension around it), "running without oil", few types of crashes, flood damage, smoker driver, "hidden damage/pearl" (something that was ignored while auctioning, so car value is different than "estimated", and you can find it by examining), parts with stars already, etc. Pick 0-3 out of that list, and restore parts of the car, not whole thing each time. 
would make restorations much more interesting, and less repetitive. I am sure devs could find a way for it to be great. Hide some of the modifiers from us when we buy a car, and show some, and it will not get boring for a while. 

btw, auctions suck, they are to consistently knowing value of the car. Please modify their ranges so they stop bidding in 80-130% range of car value.

It's weird to recommend this game because it's more useful for someone who knows absolutely nothing about cars than from someone who has experience with car repair. If you don't even know how to change the coolant, or what an alternator is then I recommend getting this game ASAP. It will teach you all the BASICS about car maintenance and repair. It shows you where all the MAJOR components are for the Engine, Suspension, Drive train etc. but it won't include anything detailed such as wiring, electrical system or hoses. It's the perfect game for a hobbyist who wants to learn more about cars and has plenty of stuff to do to keep you entertained for a long time.

The Bad:

The game doesn't offer enough information about the components or what they do, for a truly learning experience it should have plenty of information of what each component is and how it works. Right now the game is on a limbo where is too basic in most areas but at the same time the lack of info can make it complicated for a beginner.

The DLC is bad, some of it like the Mazda and Lotus DLC only include 2 cars and that's it. I think the Nissan one is better though. 

Quite a bit of a grind when getting started, making money and XP is really hard at the beginning and it will take some time before you can do cool stuff like car restoration from the Junk yards and barns.

Overall, I recommend this game. It has a lot of stuff to do and it can teach you the basics, but it's still a long way from a proper mechanics game. I wish in the future there is a much complex (Closer to real life) engine bay with all the components even if there are less variety in cars. It also needs an encyclopedia with a part lists, information and information on each part for people learning for the first time.

This game is honestly a must buy. I know a bit about cars because I have a mechanic father, so when I played this game and my knowledge was actually applicable, I was shocked. This game goes into great detail on things I completely forgot existed. I am not even going to lie to you, this game can provide you with enough knowledge to give a rough diagnosis on your own vehicle, which could significantly reduce prices of hiring a real mechanic. Do I think I could build an engine from scratch in real life? Hell no, but now I understand the engine more and understand what really goes into making it work. If you are someone who knows nothing about cars or everything about cars and you love gaming, this is for you. Like I said, inexperienced mechanics can gain actually useful skills from this, and seasoned mechanics will just love the detail and the ability to do the fun things about being a mechanic without having to do the stupid stuff like waiting for parts to ship or waiting for the oil to drain. It is a gem, I love this game, can't wait to plug at least another 50 hours into it!

Car Mechanic Simulator has evolved a lot since it's first release. Although it's a more entertaining game, it still has a long way to go. The game still needs a lot of polishing. Many parts still can't be painted in the booth and options in several areas of the game are still very limited. Most DLC content that was released for previous versions of this game is still not available for 2021 and may never be. As I state later, not a friendly community.

There is a small community of modders that add content to the game such as new vehicles, but the people themselves are irreproachable, and not willing to even answer questions. You're on your own. There is a discord channel where everyone seems to congregate from the developers down to the common players. Good luck getting answers from anyone. It's a very unfriendly community.

On the bright side,  the graphics in the game are very photo realistic and the game play will eat every moment of your free time if you're into this type of game. As for a recommendation, to be honest, I'm torn.

Pretty cool and I have been learning a lot for someone who only knows how to refill those car liquids in real life. But I'll only rate it as 7/10 for now. It will be better if there's at least description and trivia for each parts so I would learn their uses in the process (Example is, what is coolant and its difference from water, and why is the coolant container from latest cars have different shape from old ones).

I haven't touched if there's a mod yet, just the native game.

I enjoy the mechanics of the gameplay loop, but the mechanics of the cars is disappointingly inaccurate, as someone who has worked on cars for many years. Some things that should be intuitive have extra unnecessary steps, and many procedures are fundamentally wrong.

Some examples:
In order to pull engine heads, you must remove the camshafts (and every cap and bolt that entails). That's silly and isn't something any mechanic would do unless they were changing the camshafts.

All of the fluids besides oil are missing every other step of the process for each fluid. Brake fluid is syringed from the reservoir, but you don't drain or bleed the brakes at the wheels. Coolant is syringed from the reservoir, if there is one, otherwise it is syringed from the radiator fill cap. There is no bleeding step. Further, if there is no reservoir and you refill coolant at the radiator, you only need to fill it to roughly 3/4 full, or you can top it off as much as you like, and you are penalized for spilling fluids if you fill it until it overflows. Power steering fluid is also drained at the reservoir, but not the rack.

Occasionally there are cars that have serpentine belts and pulleys that get removed out of order. For example, the idlers before the belt, or idlers before the tensioner. There's some layouts where the alternator would be the tensioner, but you don't need to do anything at all to remove the belt.

Some cars have ignition wires, some just have coil packs and no wires, and of course there are no connections going between major components, so, no wiring harness, grounding wires, battery cables, brake lines, coolant hoses, throttle cables, fuel lines, etc...

Oil filters can typically only be removed with the car fully raised on the lift, even if the filter is obviously accessible from the hood.

The wheel bearing is removed before the hub, on all four corners. Typically you install these in the knuckle before the hub, or they're part of the hub assembly. Also, CV axles can be removed without disassembling any links at the knuckle, which is a dream fantasy lol. Typically you have to loosen the tie rod end, or a shock assembly, or an entire arm.

I've played like six hours but I'm sure to continue finding inaccuracies like these. It's a bit immersion breaking, and for some things inconvenient too. I would go on but I want to return to playing now, and that's why it's recommended.

edit:
Some things i would love to see in the future:

○ valvetrain components: valves, valve springs, porting, cylinder boring. Procedures like head decking and port polishing.
○ gaskets, and maybe even bolts in your inventory that must be restocked from a vendor. special large OEM bolts.
○ service manuals for cars instead of the guided linear path.
○ brake lines, coolant hoses, cables and wiring harnesses. Simple but realistic procedures for fluids and disconnect/reconnect.
○ special hand tools for parts that have multiple methods for disassembly. for example, ball joint pullers, pickle forks, BFH, your mom's purse.
○ make the minigames more engaging--the game for fluids should be avoiding spills, like those early web Flash games. Pulling an engine could include balancing it on the hoist. Placing the car on the lift, driving it in/out of the shop, all these things that are just radial menu clicks now could be much more immersive

In short: disappointment.

First of all: if you have played the 2018 version (as I have) you can safely give this one a miss.
It's the same game just more polished.  

There are things that seem to hint at good stuff, tuning and drag strips...but it's a big missed opportunity, if anything.

There are still a good number of things seemingly there just to mess with the player and slow your progress (eg putting you on the wrong side of the lift when you get a new car in).

The story missions dry up after a while, quite abruptly and seemingly in the middle of things: another missed opportunity ( could have used tasks to prepare cars for racing, tune them, etc )

But the biggest problem is the lack of challenge.

It's very easy, just slow, there's no problem making money (the best trick is still to get a wreck and just replace everything with all-new components) and fixing cars does not take anything but time.

You don't even need all the different tools to check what's wrong: it's clearly visible by its rust level.

No combination, no brain needed, just click-click-click.

The only way to create some semblance of a challenge is the hard mode; it'll hide a lot of information.  Still not the kind of challenge I expect from a computer game; you just need to learn where the bolts are.

I was really waiting for the game to bloom with the tuning, but alas; the story stopped and the only reason to tune cars is really for your own amusement.   Meh.

this game is a great game if you're just getting into the CMS sim games. But, it is not so when you've played CMS before.

I am a long time fan of this series and I've been playing the games ever since CMS 2014 and I was having a blast and then 2015 came along and I had even more of a blast even though that game was a bit boring and lacking in content.

the real turning point in this series was CMS 2018, it introduced so much new stuff into the game. New cars, new parts, a repair table, tuning, dyno, more tools, more customization, more skills, the ability to buy used cars and flip them for a profit. It was great fun, and I was really excited for CMS 2021.

I picked it up on release and after 10 hours or so I realized this is exactly like CMS 2018 with a fresh coat of paint, some new cars and a few QOL improvements here and there. We've been waiting 3 years for this? Everything you can do in CMS 2018 you can do here, it's no different, except for some "new" mechanics.

And I say "new" because these mechanics are in CMS 2018 but were recycled and improved for this game. Overall, this game is really disappointing for old fans of the series, but, it's a great game on it's own for people who have never played CMS before.

First of all, there is a lot of choice with vehicles.  Here’s a list of the Pro and Cons 

Pros
72 + Nissan + electric car dlcs
Scrap and upgrading parts
Paintable Parts
Fluids 
Salvage Auction
New Salon with a config a new vehicle

Cons

Restrictions on the workshop
lack of communication from Red Dot Games.

I actually enjoy the game. However as a mechanic myself, its difficult to get behind "realism" of the game. I do wish that there was a bit more. Like actually putting lugs and studs instead of the combination euro style lugs on every vehicle. Needing to remove hoses from some components before completely removing them. Other then those items, I feel they did get the basic feel of a shop. inspecting vehicles, ordering parts, and removing and replacing in the correct order was a big on for me. I also do wish there were different specs, like oil types, brake fluid types, coolant types, power steering types, and different items for each car as all cars do not have the same specs for everything. Again that's just me. A little more realism into the game would have been the perfect balance between game play and the "high level of realism" which the game developers have claimed.
Overall for a game is very well put together. However, please do your actual research into the functionality and maintenance of a car BEFORE you attempt it on your own car. Just because it's easy and you can do it in game DOESN'T mean you can do it in real life.

Pretty good game. If you have no idea how engines and cars work, this will give you the basics. Eventually, you'll be souping up some barn find and reaping the profits.

Don't worry about getting the right part, just click it to send it to your shopping list and pick it up on your tablet. You don't even have to pull away from building your car to do it.

Sure, the driving isn't Forza 5, but the focus is fixing cars while rocking out to surprisingly good tunes.

If you have even a passing interest in fixing and upgrading cars, there's no reason to wait.

The game really gets rolling once you have the cash to restore junkyard cars. The DLCs are cool and the attention to detail on engine internals is a good learning experience. Lots of fun and playability is pretty consistent until you have all the cars you want. Customization of the car, engine, shop, play style, is very wide. 

Once you've amassed a couple million credits and have some nice cars to rip on the track, it can be difficult to find stuff to do. I know it may not be within the scope of a mechanic sim, but more tracks or some form of competition amongst players would continue to breath life into the endgame.

I really enjoyed this game for the time I was able to play it then I tried to change the in-game settings, seemingly corrupted my save file in doing so, and realized I would have to start over if I wanted to keep playing. This sort of game-breaking situation just isn't acceptable. Thank goodness I wasn't deeper into the game I guess. Here's the fuller story:

First, I ran low on money as I was completing a job. I tried to disable the cost to travel to other locations b/c I couldn't afford the fee for the junkyard. I changed the settings mid-game, and then when I tried to travel to the junkyard I got a black screen and the game would never load. I tried reverting the change, saving, going to the main screen, then changing the settings from there (rather than within my session), and still no dice.

Okay, I guess I'll take on additional jobs that are cheap to make some money so I can afford the expensive part for the previous job. I complete the repairs on this second job and try to finish the job by changing out the fluids. But the Drain Tool won't work b/c the game is in the middle of auto-saving. It stays mid-save and never completes. I give up and quit out, do some of the job over again, and this time try to manually save. Still no dice. At this point I just give up since I seemingly can't save the game any longer.

Also: Apparently there used to be a few cheat codes in the 2018 version so if you were like me and found yourself low on funds you could just cheat past it. It seems they removed this in the 2021 version. A pity for "casuals" like me who just wanted to enjoy the process of working on cars and don't care about the "business" aspect.

After quite a few hours with this game and being a retired Mechanic (46yrs), I would gladly give it an 8/10 rating. The few gripes I have, can't paint every part as you would be able to IRL makes it impossible to get the precise look you wanted. And the lack of modification ability (would be great to be able to convert drum brakes to disc brakes, or slap on a turbo, etc.) The biggest gripe is the "Repair" minigame, it has nothing to do with developed skill within the game and is all about reaction time, at my age my reactions are way too slow to secure any hope of an actual repair, even though the part is repairable. The plus side, there is just enough bolt tightening to remind you that you are working, but not so much to make it a tedium, graphics is great and I really enjoy the finished look. Even ppl that have had no experience with cars can get into an understanding of how cars are put together, and can have an enjoyable pastime in the process. Now give me a way to clean up my garage...
vroom vroom wrench wrench very nice, graphics ok. they need to add more performance parts so stuff can be more shinny. like engine blocks could have a bit more shine. also a bit more engine swaps
half of my mods dont have engines but i make like 20k off of cleaning them. pretty fun though honestly.

Rating 0/10 for realism .. you can't put oil in without the oil pan/bolt and filter in. Everyone does it at least once IRL ;)

Oh CMS, you have always had so much potential, yet you continue to refine the same formula. They've added some new minigames from 2018, but the core remains unchanged, and that's not necessarily bad. The minigames mostly boil down to click here to stop the ticker type games.. not really engaging.

If you enjoyed 2015/2018 this is more of the same with a bit more polish.  The cars are greatly detailed, and the components are accurate enough to teach folks a bit about what that doodad or thingymajig is called. There is more than enough to have fun in the base game, I'd only recommend the DLC's if you really enjoy that brand of vehicle, otherwise there is really not much point. The vehicle tuning system is unexplained, and really gives no guidance. The vehicle handling is terrible... so basically just like 2018. The story missions are completely irrelevant. It's just another job with a paragraph of flavor text. You never really get any depth or connections. It's really a missed opportunity imo.

That being said though, all in all It's a great way to click away some time if you enjoy feeling like you took a piece of junk and make it shiny and go vroom!

Some suggestions for improvement:
1. Give a Info button that will give basic information about parts and how they work to further educate folks.
2. Expert mode should allow you to fail a job by missing a part without warning you.
3. Add some tuning tools to the Dyno shop to allow you to tune without over-tuning to ridiculous. Maybe expert mode should allow for blowing out components if you really get crazy.
4. Create an actual story-line, maybe you get signed up to be a mechanic for a a race team, maybe you work with a Baja offroad team, maybe you work on Top Gear like show I don't know.. something more than "I crashed my car fix it." followed by "Oh you did good here's my uncles car, fix it too."
5. Improve the handling or get rid of it the track. It's kind of pointless in it's current state.

The game has a lot more potential.. after this 3rd release, please do more than make it shinier and clickier.

I have to say I am pleasantly surprised with the quality of this game. As a professional mechanic for 6 years and a lifetime automotive enthusiast, I can say this game fully satisfies those interests. It takes all the aspects that I loved about being a mechanic and leaves out things I hated, while also adding in all the things I love about cars as a hobby. The cars and parts are detailed and accurate, but also simplified so as not to become totally unmanageable. The visuals are beautiful, and it's so rewarding to see the results of an old rust bucket being fully restored. 

I would say I'm 100% the target audience for a game like this, but I think a lot of people who wouldn't expect to like a game like this would actually find enjoyment out of it, and you don't need any prior automotive experience or education. The process is intuitive and systematic enough that anyone would be able to do the work / play the game. For those with no background knowledge, I think this would be a fun way to become familiar with how cars are put together.

To the team: 

Thank you very much for your efforts putting together such a great game!

This game is just next-level awesome. Anyone remotely into cars should immediately purchase it, I just can't recommend it highly enough. I don't think I exaggerate when I say it's the best game I've ever played.

That said, it's not without faults. It's not perfect. But no game is, and they've done such an awesome job on this it deserves the accolades I gave it. The fact that there's room to improve it just makes me excited for the future - upcoming DLCs and past that, the next versions.

The whole game is fantastic but I really have to give credit to the driving physics. I've read some other reviewers say they're not up-to-par but my opinion is that they're just perfect. I've been playing racing simulators since NASCAR Racing 2 all the way up to iRacing, and no, they're not iRacing-level realistic or detailed, but that's expected since the main focus is on building the cars, not driving them.

That said, the physics are still really good. They hit a perfect balance between difficult-realism and arcade-fun. I do laps and laps on the racetrack in my creations just for fun. One thing that is sorely missing is the ability to watch & save replays.

There are many things missing actually, but like I said, it just makes me excited for the future. The game as it stands is AAA.
