[b] TL;DR: [/b] Simulation is fun. You can easily spend hours working on a single car. Game appears to have no bugs so far.


In real life I'm no mechanic, but I can replace a few parts and drain and change most of the fluids. I bought all the DLC and the game during this summer sale, I'll update this review as I play more and get used to the game:

[hr][/hr]

[b] 1 hour: [/b] I pop a car hood and everything is pretty easy to see at a glance. No tubing or wires blocking the view. The starting vehicles also seem to be very roomy under the hood, so you don't hassle with mis-clicks too often.

[hr][/hr]

[b] 7 hours: [/b] Mostly fixing suspension systems and brakes. Fixing up cars is fun and I'm excited to get back onto it to see how the other stuff is built.

[hr][/hr]

[b] 12 hours: [/b] [spoiler] Transmission and engine work is tossed into the mix on top of suspension and brakes. It's still fun but some parts of the gameplay begin to feel a tad tedious. The design of some cars internals are terribly laid out. It's probably accurate to the actual cars, but still a pain in the neck to work on. For example, having to remove large pipes to reach the oil cap is a design I never thought I'd see, and I hate it. Some cars also have the radiator/cooler so tightly against the engine that it becomes difficult to take off timing belts and pulleys. I have upgraded Bolt removal to Max level. [/spoiler]

[hr][/hr]

[b] 19 hours: [/b] [spoiler] Bought paint shop and a bunch of other stuff for a job that I couldn't finish for the life of me. Here is a tip from my learning experience: If your car isn't coming up as "Painted" after painting it, make sure you have all the body parts attached (including all windows and Mirrors), and repaint it. [/spoiler]

[hr][/hr]

[b] 23 hours: [/b] [spoiler] I'm getting a tad sick of taking off tires for everything and have decided to mostly work on engines now. Game tip 2: Steering Rack below engine can be an engine problem (I can't escape the tires D:). Additionally, my annoyance with removing tires and their bolts has now transferred over to engine Valves and Rockers. I'm hoping leveling my examination time will make that process faster... [/spoiler]

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 is the worst Car Mechanic Simulator game available.

This game takes Car Mechanic Simulator 2018 and gives it a "new coat of paint" to say the least, it updates Unity to LTS 2021, this gives better performance, newer features, security updates and reliability. However, this does not account for the developers lack of creativity and inconsistencies, why would a mechanic garage be placed in the middle of a desert with vehicles driving by semi-regularly, why do we have a relatively modern and up to date workshop in what seems like the middle of nowhere.

Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 does so many things wrong it makes me regret buying this game. When you're running the game at high graphics you have a filter over the game that makes it feel cartoony and unpleasant, most vehicle content and part content is slapped from Car Mechanic Simulator 2018 into Car Mechanic Simulator 2021, they made no effort in redesigning the license plates from Car Mechanic Simulator 2018 and just added them to Car Mechanic Simulator 2021, some of the beneficial additions they've made would be liquids like coolants and hydraulic fluids, electrical boxes and a very basic form of EUC's, they've added the ability for cars to be missing parts of their suspension and even missing wheels, which Car Mechanic Simulator 2018 didn't have and sorely needed, this is a genuine improvement but what's not an improvement is the removal of the third car lift, the duplication of body and part repair stations, why do I need more than one body and part repair station? Why move the engine crane to a separate room rather than have it on the same floor as the vehicles you're working on?

Even though I find the Campaign a useless feature, you can somewhat easily make yourself bankrupt in the campaign, which makes it basically useless if you're not good at business/finance simulators.

The games UI/UX is so inconsistent it hurts, and the most glaring question of all, what are you supposed to do when you've repaired all the cars you can get your hands on? Start over again, buy more DLC? This game is even worse when it comes to repetition, because they haven't solved it, they just think feeding us more base vehicles, parts to replace/repair and more DLC will satisfy use, they don't seem to care about listening to the fans even though they probably would disagree with me, but as a fan I know none of my concerns have been heard nor even taken into account, and I know other fans haven't had their concerns or voices heard either.

This game shouldn't exist, the time gone into developing this should've been put into Car Mechanic Simulator 2018, they're only making year incremental games to rake in more money and screw over current fans and new fans, I'm getting sick of the quality of games PlayWay S.A. is making themselves and getting companies/developers to make and even worse, I would recommend Car Mechanic Simulator 2018 over Car Mechanic Simulator 2021 any day, not only for the great community content that we currently have, but also due to the amount of DLC (Downloadable content) at our finger tips at a relatively cheap price (Average $7 AUD), the fact the game doesn't bog you down with too many decisions and options.

TL;DR: Car Mechanic Simulator 2018 with a "new coat of paint", ignoring fans, inconsistencies, a few more QoL features and performance fixes and less DLC than Car Mechanic Simulator 2018, save your money, do not buy.

I originally played this game when it was first released, reviewed it then sought a refund.  Since this game came bundled with another title I can now leave a better review of the game now that I have toured the new features and had some additional play time and I came away with this: Save your money.  

This game is not revolutionary compared to 2018 if anything its a light refresher, some graphical enhancements and few mini games added and the overall shop layout has been spread out but that about all there is.  All the same cars from the previous games, all the same DLC's for the most part and basically the same interface.

While I think its cool that the developers have streamlined this title with each new iteration, I don't feel like there is enough innovation to warrant the asking price, especially with all the same DLC's that must be bought all over again when they could have just been included.

There is still no interior customization beyond changing out seats and steering wheels.  There really isn't much customization period.  If you take away the performance parts that are mostly engine related, you're left with brakes and that's it.  Can't lower or jack up your rides, no lift kits, dash kits, body kits, etc.   I get bored easily and I find the core mechanic aspect to be very tedious and can get really boring as its literally one job after the next.  I used to really enjoy buying junkers to fix up and sell but most vehicles have very generic drivetrain's and as previously mentioned the only really wow factors are modded engine parts and brakes.  Paint and Livery is the same as previous installments.

So to sum it up, the mini-games are meh, I don't like the spread out shops, the car washing feature is pretty lame.  You could just buy CMS2018 and be just as happy unless you need to have every version.  Granted the game has improved substantially since it debuted in 2014 but the pace of game improvements slowed right down after CMS 2018 which makes CMS 2021 a poor value.

This game is very good. I am a bit tired of all the bugs that games have these days. It was a really nice experience to play this game. 190 hours and the only bugs I encountered where when I used a mod from  the Steam workshop. The game has a nice progression where you slowly get more money and experience. In the beginning you will repair cars and in the end you will make cool cars for your own fun. You can trim, paint, choose different body parts etc to make the car as you like it. You can also test drive the cars on a strip or a race track. I learned a lot about parts and how to assemble and disassemble them. The graphics are good and so are the details. I skipped the ultra setting of graphics. because then my computer ran hot. Something wrong with the programming there. I do recommend you to download a small mod to get the real car names. That is a game changer. I really recommend this game!

Dickhead customer sends me a totaled car. "Ok that's some work but it can be done." says me who still haven't noticed every trip to the scrapyard costs 500 credits. Stil, got a couple components in good conditions there, so there's that.
Now with just barely enough money to operate I pick up another job to make a profit. And then another... And another one, this one is so full of problems I nearly lose all funds.
Realizing I don't have the money to actually finish any of the contracts I've accepted, I start being even more selective on which ones to pick: Simple, Predictable, preferably with pricy components I can actually cover and with a payout bonus. In the meantime have to sell a couple of those components I found at the scrapyard.
Finally I fix that car for over 4000 credits, just enough to not have to worry about money as much, finish another couple of jobs and then finally finish the first, totaled car.
The final payout is big enouh for me to actually start expanding. All is good in the world.

I recommend this game if you like going near bankrupt looking at garbage.

I enjoyed CMS 2018 VERY much when I had it. I have been looking for a new game to get into and enjoy, and this is it! 

I have been so hesitant about picking this up. I wasn't sure if it would be worth it since I have 2018. Well, it was very worth the purchase! The new, far more interactive tools like the wheel balancer, and repair bench, to name two things, make the game feel more involved and enjoyable! For the most part, its close to the same as 2018, but its one of those things where, instead of redoing the whole game, and risking ruining it, they took what worked well, and built off of it more. New locations like the junkyard, and car auction make the game VERY enjoyable as well! I love going to the junkyard, finding cool cars, and rebuilding them for (most of the time) profit. 

There are a couple things I didn't like. The workshop contains items that you need DLC for most of. The thing I liked about 2018 was the fact that people made mods that would replace DLC cars, and the modded cars would just use base game engines. I only purchased two DLC's because of that. 

I also wish you could do more with the cars after building them. I usually buy junkyard cars and rebuild them, but when I am done, that's just it. It's still satisfying, but I just wish there was more!

The game is a bit of a grind. but I don't mind. This game is so amazing to play while watching YouTube or a stream. So yeah! If you enjoyed CMS 2018, and are on the fence about this, I would do it, I mean, I did. It was very much so worth it to me! I also got it on sale for $20, which again, I found to be worth it. 

I do plan to buy DLC once I get bored of the base game, but I don't see that happening too soon!

I just want to say quick too, I see a lot of people saying this game is "extremely realistic" and such. It really is not, however, it is a great start to learning about cars and parts! And this is an extremely fun game to just sit relax and enjoy if you like cars! But it is far from being extremely realistic! Just wanted to say that!

This is without doubt a great game and a massive improvement over CMS 2018. There are many new features to like, including the new auction system which has a much more friendly sound when bidding rather than the harsh sound of previous.

The game play is much smoother, has lots of new repair features, and i love the painting options compared to before. The immersion of the game feels a lot more like a mechanic game and therefore this definitely gets the thumbs up!

New features in this game over CMS 2018

Car wash
Much better paint options
Much larger and extended repair work (body work, brake lathe etc)
Missing part locator
Extended catalogue of much more parts
Many more cars
Overall very smooth gameplay and quick loading times

The following are some bits which in my humble opinion could or should be added in the next update, for ease / convenience and also immersion. 

1. Inventory vs warehouse. = There should be a "transfer all" button when you want to empty your inventory into the warehouse and vice versa. I accumulated a HUGE amount of parts and it took forever trying to transfer pages upon pages of parts into the warehouse. You can easily sell off all your items but I wanted only to keep a few in my inventory and clear the rest out, however this took ages and my fingers were killing me after 400 or so pages later.....

2. Personal space / office. = In CMS 2018 you had an office which had desks etc and then a rest area upstairs. This game has neither as far as I can tell. There is a section next to the warehouse on the right with a door that says "push" but I cant access it.

3. Perhaps the biggest gripe and need for improvement is down to the handling of the cars, ESPECIALLY once you have managed to upgrade the power. With some cars, no matter how little the gains, the handling is all over the place, the car becomes un-driveable and therefore you cannot enjoy the experience. Not only does this take away the little bit of realism but it also kills any fun you were expecting. No matter what you do, put on slicks, better brakes etc you just cant get the power down without sliding all over the place.

Thats all I can think of at the minute. The above 2 items by no means take anything away from the game. Just something I would like to see in the game to complete the experience.

Overall worth buying if you like tinkering with cars!

cons - these are minor gripes - you don't really get to deal with any of the electical wiring or any tubing for air filters or even any of the pipes for stuff like the power steering to power steering pump or bake pipes from the brake salve to caliper. these would have been nice little touches.

more ramps would have been nice if nothing else woulda been better if there was 3 ramps/lifts to match the external parking space 

all in all the pros outweigh the cons
